dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Call here my varlet; I'll unarm again. Why should I war without the walls of Troy That find such cruel battle here within? Each Trojan that is master of his heart, Let him to field; Troilus, alas! hath none.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Will this gear ne'er be mended?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: The Greeks are strong, and skilful to their strength, Fierce to their skill, and to their fierceness valiant; But I am weaker than a woman's tear, Tamer than sleep, fonder than ignorance, Less valiant than the virgin in the night, And skilless as unpractis'd infancy.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Well, I have told you enough of this; for my part, I'll not meddle nor make no farther. He that will have a cake out of the wheat must tarry the grinding.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Have I not tarried?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ay, the grinding; but you must tarry the bolting.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Have I not tarried?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ay, the bolting; but you must tarry the leavening.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Still have I tarried.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ay, to the leavening; but here's yet in the word ‘hereafter' the kneading, the making of the cake, the heating of the oven, and the baking; nay, you must stay the cooling too, or you may chance burn your lips.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Patience herself, what goddess e'er she be, Doth lesser blench at suff'rance than I do. At Priam's royal table do I sit; And when fair Cressid comes into my thoughts, So, traitor! ‘when she comes'! when she is thence?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Well, she look'd yesternight fairer than ever I saw her look, or any woman else.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I was about to tell thee: when my heart, As wedged with a sigh, would rive in twain, Lest Hector or my father should perceive me, I have, as when the sun doth light a storm, Buried this sigh in wrinkle of a smile. But sorrow that is couch'd in seeming gladness Is like that mirth fate turns to sudden sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: An her hair were not somewhat darker than Helen's, well, go to, there were no more comparison between the women. But, for my part, she is my kinswoman; I would not, as they term it, praise her, but I would somebody had heard her talk yesterday, as I did. I will not dispraise your sister Cassandra's wit; but-

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O Pandarus! I tell thee, Pandarus, When I do tell thee there my hopes lie drown'd, Reply not in how many fathoms deep They lie indrench'd. I tell thee I am mad In Cressid's love. Thou answer'st ‘She is fair'; Pour'st in the open ulcer of my heart Her eyes, her hair, her cheek, her gait, her voice, Handlest in thy discourse. O! that her hand, In whose comparison all whites are ink Writing their own reproach; to whose soft seizure The cygnet's down is harsh, and spirit of sense Hard as the palm of ploughman! This thou tell'st me, As true thou tell'st me, when I say I love her; But, saying thus, instead of oil and balm, Thou lay'st in every gash that love hath given me The knife that made it.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I speak no more than truth.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Thou dost not speak so much.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Faith, I'll not meddle in't. Let her be as she is: if she be fair, 'tis the better for her; and she be not, she has the mends in her own hands.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Good Pandarus! How now, Pandarus!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I have had my labour for my travail, ill thought on of her and ill thought on of you; gone between and between, but small thanks for my labour.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: What! art thou angry, Pandarus? What! with me?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Because she's kin to me, therefore she's not so fair as Helen. And she were not kin to me, she would be as fair on Friday as Helen is on Sunday. But what care I? I care not and she were a blackamoor; 'tis all one to me.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Say I she is not fair?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I do not care whether you do or no. She's a fool to stay behind her father. Let her to the Greeks; and so I'll tell her the next time I see her. For my part, I'll meddle nor make no more i' the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Pandarus-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Not I.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Sweet Pandarus-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Pray you, speak no more to me: I will leave all as I found it, and there an end.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Peace, you ungracious clamours! Peace, rude sounds! Fools on both sides! Helen must needs be fair, When with your blood you daily paint her thus. I cannot fight upon this argument; It is too starv'd a subject for my sword. But Pandarus, O gods! how do you plague me! I cannot come to Cressid but by Pandar; And he's as tetchy to be woo'd to woo As she is stubborn-chaste against all suit. Tell me, Apollo, for thy Daphne's love, What Cressid is, what Pandar, and what we? Her bed is India; there she lies, a pearl; Between our Ilium and where she resides Let it be call'd the wild and wandering flood; Ourself the merchant, and this sailing Pandar Our doubtful hope, our convoy, and our bark. Alarum. Enter Aeneas.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: How now, Prince Troilus! Wherefore not afield?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Because not there. This woman's answer sorts, For womanish it is to be from thence. What news, Aeneas, from the field today?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: That Paris is returned home, and hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: By whom, Aeneas?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Troilus, by Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Let Paris bleed: 'tis but a scar to scorn; Paris is gor'd with Menelaus' horn.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Hark what good sport is out of town today!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Better at home, if ‘would I might' were ‘may.' But to the sport abroad. Are you bound thither?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: In all swift haste.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Come, go we then together.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Who were those went by?

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: Queen Hecuba and Helen.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: And whither go they?

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: Up to the eastern tower, Whose height commands as subject all the vale, To see the battle. Hector, whose patience Is as a virtue fix'd, today was mov'd. He chid Andromache, and struck his armourer; And, like as there were husbandry in war, Before the sun rose he was harness'd light, And to the field goes he; where every flower Did as a prophet weep what it foresaw In Hector's wrath.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: What was his cause of anger?

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: The noise goes, this: there is among the Greeks A lord of Trojan blood, nephew to Hector; They call him Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Good; and what of him?

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: They say he is a very man _per se_ And stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: So do all men, unless they are drunk, sick, or have no legs.

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: This man, lady, hath robb'd many beasts of their particular additions: he is as valiant as the lion, churlish as the bear, slow as the elephant-a man into whom nature hath so crowded humours that his valour is crush'd into folly, his folly sauced with discretion. There is no man hath a virtue that he hath not a glimpse of, nor any man an attaint but he carries some stain of it; he is melancholy without cause and merry against the hair; he hath the joints of everything; but everything so out of joint that he is a gouty Briareus, many hands and no use, or purblind Argus, all eyes and no sight.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: But how should this man, that makes me smile, make Hector angry?

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: They say he yesterday cop'd Hector in the battle and struck him down, the disdain and shame whereof hath ever since kept Hector fasting and waking.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: Madam, your uncle Pandarus.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Hector's a gallant man.

dialogues.speaker: Alexander
dialogues.line: As may be in the world, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What's that? What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Good morrow, uncle Pandarus.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Good morrow, cousin Cressid. What do you talk of?-Good morrow, Alexander.-How do you, cousin? When were you at Ilium?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: This morning, uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What were you talking of when I came? Was Hector arm'd and gone ere you came to Ilium? Helen was not up, was she?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Hector was gone; but Helen was not up.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: E'en so. Hector was stirring early.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: That were we talking of, and of his anger.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Was he angry?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: So he says here.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: True, he was so; I know the cause too; he'll lay about him today, I can tell them that. And there's Troilus will not come far behind him; let them take heed of Troilus, I can tell them that too.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: What, is he angry too?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Who, Troilus? Troilus is the better man of the two.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O Jupiter! there's no comparison.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What, not between Troilus and Hector? Do you know a man if you see him?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Ay, if I ever saw him before and knew him.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Well, I say Troilus is Troilus.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Then you say as I say, for I am sure he is not Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: No, nor Hector is not Troilus in some degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: 'Tis just to each of them: he is himself.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Himself! Alas, poor Troilus! I would he were!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: So he is.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Condition I had gone barefoot to India.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: He is not Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Himself! no, he's not himself. Would a' were himself! Well, the gods are above; time must friend or end. Well, Troilus, well! I would my heart were in her body! No, Hector is not a better man than Troilus.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: He is elder.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Pardon me, pardon me.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Th'other's not come to't; you shall tell me another tale when th'other's come to't. Hector shall not have his wit this year.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: He shall not need it if he have his own.

dialogues.speaker: Andarus
dialogues.line: Nor his qualities.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: No matter.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Nor his beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: 'Twould not become him: his own's better.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You have no judgement, niece. Helen herself swore th'other day that Troilus, for a brown favour, for so 'tis, I must confess-not brown neither-

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: No, but brown.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Faith, to say truth, brown and not brown.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: To say the truth, true and not true.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: She prais'd his complexion above Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Why, Paris hath colour enough.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: So he has.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Then Troilus should have too much. If she prais'd him above, his complexion is higher than his; he having colour enough, and the other higher, is too flaming a praise for a good complexion. I had as lief Helen's golden tongue had commended Troilus for a copper nose.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I swear to you I think Helen loves him better than Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Then she's a merry Greek indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Nay, I am sure she does. She came to him th'other day into the compass'd window-and you know he has not past three or four hairs on his chin-

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Indeed a tapster's arithmetic may soon bring his particulars therein to a total.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Why, he is very young, and yet will he within three pound lift as much as his brother Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Is he so young a man and so old a lifter?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: But to prove to you that Helen loves him: she came and puts me her white hand to his cloven chin-

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Juno have mercy! How came it cloven?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Why, you know, 'tis dimpled. I think his smiling becomes him better than any man in all Phrygia.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O, he smiles valiantly!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Does he not?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O yes, an 'twere a cloud in autumn!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Why, go to, then! But to prove to you that Helen loves Troilus-

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Troilus will stand to the proof, if you'll prove it so.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Troilus! Why, he esteems her no more than I esteem an addle egg.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: If you love an addle egg as well as you love an idle head, you would eat chickens i' th' shell.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I cannot choose but laugh to think how she tickled his chin. Indeed, she has a marvell's white hand, I must needs confess.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Without the rack.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: And she takes upon her to spy a white hair on his chin.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Alas, poor chin! Many a wart is richer.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: But there was such laughing! Queen Hecuba laugh'd that her eyes ran o'er.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: With millstones.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: And Cassandra laugh'd.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: But there was a more temperate fire under the pot of her eyes. Did her eyes run o'er too?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: And Hector laugh'd.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: At what was all this laughing?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Marry, at the white hair that Helen spied on Troilus' chin.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: And't had been a green hair I should have laugh'd too.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: They laugh'd not so much at the hair as at his pretty answer.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: What was his answer?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Quoth she ‘Here's but two and fifty hairs on your chin, and one of them is white.'

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: This is her question.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: That's true; make no question of that. ‘Two and fifty hairs,' quoth he ‘and one white. That white hair is my father, and all the rest are his sons.' ‘Jupiter!' quoth she ‘which of these hairs is Paris my husband?' ‘The forked one,' quoth he, 'pluck't out and give it him.' But there was such laughing! and Helen so blush'd, and Paris so chaf'd; and all the rest so laugh'd that it pass'd.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: So let it now; for it has been a great while going by.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Well, cousin, I told you a thing yesterday; think on't.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: So I do.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I'll be sworn 'tis true; he will weep you, and 'twere a man born in April.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: And I'll spring up in his tears, an 'twere a nettle against May.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Hark! they are coming from the field. Shall we stand up here and see them as they pass toward Ilium? Good niece, do, sweet niece Cressida.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: At your pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Here, here, here's an excellent place; here we may see most bravely. I'll tell you them all by their names as they pass by; but mark Troilus above the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Speak not so loud.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: That's Aeneas. Is not that a brave man? He's one of the flowers of Troy, I can tell you. But mark Troilus; you shall see anon.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: That's Antenor. He has a shrewd wit, I can tell you; and he's a man good enough; he's one o' th' soundest judgements in Troy, whosoever, and a proper man of person. When comes Troilus? I'll show you Troilus anon. If he see me, you shall see him nod at me.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Will he give you the nod?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You shall see.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: If he do, the rich shall have more.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: That's Hector, that, that, look you, that; there's a fellow! Go thy way, Hector! There's a brave man, niece. O brave Hector! Look how he looks. There's a countenance! Is't not a brave man?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O, a brave man!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Is a' not? It does a man's heart good. Look you what hacks are on his helmet! Look you yonder, do you see? Look you there. There's no jesting; there's laying on; take't off who will, as they say. There be hacks.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Be those with swords?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Swords! anything, he cares not; and the devil come to him, it's all one. By God's lid, it does one's heart good. Yonder comes Paris, yonder comes Paris. Look ye yonder, niece; is't not a gallant man too, is't not? Why, this is brave now. Who said he came hurt home today? He's not hurt. Why, this will do Helen's heart good now, ha! Would I could see Troilus now! You shall see Troilus anon.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: That's Helenus. I marvel where Troilus is. That's Helenus. I think he went not forth today. That's Helenus.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Can Helenus fight, uncle?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Helenus! no. Yes, he'll fight indifferent well. I marvel where Troilus is. Hark! do you not hear the people cry ‘Troilus'?-Helenus is a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: What sneaking fellow comes yonder?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Where? yonder? That's Deiphobus. 'Tis Troilus. There's a man, niece. Hem! Brave Troilus, the prince of chivalry!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Peace, for shame, peace!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Mark him; note him. O brave Troilus! Look well upon him, niece; look you how his sword is bloodied, and his helm more hack'd than Hector's; and how he looks, and how he goes! O admirable youth! he never saw three and twenty. Go thy way, Troilus, go thy way. Had I a sister were a grace or a daughter a goddess, he should take his choice. O admirable man! Paris? Paris is dirt to him; and, I warrant, Helen, to change, would give an eye to boot.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Here comes more.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Asses, fools, dolts! chaff and bran, chaff and bran! porridge after meat! I could live and die in the eyes of Troilus. Ne'er look, ne'er look; the eagles are gone. Crows and daws, crows and daws! I had rather be such a man as Troilus than Agamemnon and all Greece.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: There is amongst the Greeks Achilles, a better man than Troilus.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Achilles? A drayman, a porter, a very camel!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Well, well.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Well, well! Why, have you any discretion? Have you any eyes? Do you know what a man is? Is not birth, beauty, good shape, discourse, manhood, learning, gentleness, virtue, youth, liberality, and such like, the spice and salt that season a man?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Ay, a minc'd man; and then to be bak'd with no date in the pie, for then the man's date is out.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You are such a woman! A man knows not at what ward you lie.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Upon my back, to defend my belly; upon my wit, to defend my wiles; upon my secrecy, to defend mine honesty; my mask, to defend my beauty; and you, to defend all these; and at all these wards I lie, at a thousand watches.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Say one of your watches.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll watch you for that; and that's one of the chiefest of them too. If I cannot ward what I would not have hit, I can watch you for telling how I took the blow; unless it swell past hiding, and then it's past watching.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You are such another! Enter Troilus' Boy.

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: Sir, my lord would instantly speak with you.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: At your own house; there he unarms him.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Good boy, tell him I come.  I doubt he be hurt. Fare ye well, good niece.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Adieu, uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I will be with you, niece, by and by.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: To bring, uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ay, a token from Troilus.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: By the same token, you are a bawd. Words, vows, gifts, tears, and love's full sacrifice, He offers in another's enterprise; But more in Troilus thousand-fold I see Than in the glass of Pandar's praise may be, Yet hold I off. Women are angels, wooing: Things won are done; joy's soul lies in the doing. That she belov'd knows naught that knows not this: Men prize the thing ungain'd more than it is. That she was never yet that ever knew Love got so sweet as when desire did sue; Therefore this maxim out of love I teach: ‘Achievement is command; ungain'd, beseech.' Then though my heart's content firm love doth bear, Nothing of that shall from mine eyes appear.

scenes.location: The Grecian camp. Before Agamemnon's tent.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Princes, What grief hath set these jaundies o'er your cheeks? The ample proposition that hope makes In all designs begun on earth below Fails in the promis'd largeness; checks and disasters Grow in the veins of actions highest rear'd, As knots, by the conflux of meeting sap, Infects the sound pine, and diverts his grain Tortive and errant from his course of growth. Nor, princes, is it matter new to us That we come short of our suppose so far That after seven years' siege yet Troy walls stand; Sith every action that hath gone before, Whereof we have record, trial did draw Bias and thwart, not answering the aim, And that unbodied figure of the thought That gave't surmised shape. Why then, you princes, Do you with cheeks abash'd behold our works And call them shames, which are, indeed, naught else But the protractive trials of great Jove To find persistive constancy in men; The fineness of which metal is not found In fortune's love? For then the bold and coward, The wise and fool, the artist and unread, The hard and soft, seem all affin'd and kin. But in the wind and tempest of her frown Distinction, with a broad and powerful fan, Puffing at all, winnows the light away; And what hath mass or matter by itself Lies rich in virtue and unmingled.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: With due observance of thy godlike seat, Great Agamemnon, Nestor shall apply Thy latest words. In the reproof of chance Lies the true proof of men. The sea being smooth, How many shallow bauble boats dare sail Upon her patient breast, making their way With those of nobler bulk! But let the ruffian Boreas once enrage The gentle Thetis, and anon behold The strong-ribb'd bark through liquid mountains cut, Bounding between the two moist elements Like Perseus' horse. Where's then the saucy boat, Whose weak untimber'd sides but even now Co-rivall'd greatness? Either to harbour fled Or made a toast for Neptune. Even so Doth valour's show and valour's worth divide In storms of fortune; for in her ray and brightness The herd hath more annoyance by the breeze Than by the tiger; but when the splitting wind Makes flexible the knees of knotted oaks, And flies fled under shade-why, then the thing of courage, As rous'd with rage, with rage doth sympathise, And with an accent tun'd in self-same key Retorts to chiding fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Agamemnon, Thou great commander, nerve and bone of Greece, Heart of our numbers, soul and only spirit In whom the tempers and the minds of all Should be shut up-hear what Ulysses speaks. Besides th'applause and approbation The which,  most mighty, for thy place and sway,  And, thou most reverend, for thy stretch'd-out life, I give to both your speeches-which were such As Agamemnon and the hand of Greece Should hold up high in brass; and such again As venerable Nestor, hatch'd in silver, Should with a bond of air, strong as the axle-tree On which heaven rides, knit all the Greekish ears To his experienc'd tongue-yet let it please both, Thou great, and wise, to hear Ulysses speak.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Speak, Prince of Ithaca; and be't of less expect That matter needless, of importless burden, Divide thy lips than we are confident, When rank Thersites opes his mastic jaws, We shall hear music, wit, and oracle.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Troy, yet upon his basis, had been down, And the great Hector's sword had lack'd a master, But for these instances: The specialty of rule hath been neglected; And look how many Grecian tents do stand Hollow upon this plain, so many hollow factions. When that the general is not like the hive, To whom the foragers shall all repair, What honey is expected? Degree being vizarded, Th'unworthiest shows as fairly in the mask. The heavens themselves, the planets, and this centre, Observe degree, priority, and place, Insisture, course, proportion, season, form, Office, and custom, in all line of order; And therefore is the glorious planet Sol In noble eminence enthron'd and spher'd Amidst the other, whose med'cinable eye Corrects the influence of evil planets, And posts, like the commandment of a king, Sans check, to good and bad. But when the planets In evil mixture to disorder wander, What plagues and what portents, what mutiny, What raging of the sea, shaking of earth, Commotion in the winds! Frights, changes, horrors, Divert and crack, rend and deracinate, The unity and married calm of states Quite from their fixture! O, when degree is shak'd, Which is the ladder of all high designs, The enterprise is sick! How could communities, Degrees in schools, and brotherhoods in cities, Peaceful commerce from dividable shores, The primogenity and due of birth, Prerogative of age, crowns, sceptres, laurels, But by degree stand in authentic place? Take but degree away, untune that string, And hark what discord follows! Each thing melts In mere oppugnancy: the bounded waters Should lift their bosoms higher than the shores, And make a sop of all this solid globe; Strength should be lord of imbecility, And the rude son should strike his father dead; Force should be right; or, rather, right and wrong- Between whose endless jar justice resides- Should lose their names, and so should justice too. Then everything includes itself in power, Power into will, will into appetite; And appetite, an universal wolf, So doubly seconded with will and power, Must make perforce an universal prey, And last eat up himself. Great Agamemnon, This chaos, when degree is suffocate, Follows the choking. And this neglection of degree it is That by a pace goes backward, with a purpose It hath to climb. The general's disdain'd By him one step below, he by the next, That next by him beneath; so every step, Exampl'd by the first pace that is sick Of his superior, grows to an envious fever Of pale and bloodless emulation. And 'tis this fever that keeps Troy on foot, Not her own sinews. To end a tale of length, Troy in our weakness stands, not in her strength.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Most wisely hath Ulysses here discover'd The fever whereof all our power is sick.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: The nature of the sickness found, Ulysses, What is the remedy?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: The great Achilles, whom opinion crowns The sinew and the forehand of our host, Having his ear full of his airy fame, Grows dainty of his worth, and in his tent Lies mocking our designs; with him Patroclus Upon a lazy bed the livelong day Breaks scurril jests; And with ridiculous and awkward action- Which, slanderer, he imitation calls- He pageants us. Sometime, great Agamemnon, Thy topless deputation he puts on; And like a strutting player whose conceit Lies in his hamstring, and doth think it rich To hear the wooden dialogue and sound 'Twixt his stretch'd footing and the scaffoldage- Such to-be-pitied and o'er-wrested seeming He acts thy greatness in; and when he speaks 'Tis like a chime a-mending; with terms unsquar'd, Which, from the tongue of roaring Typhon dropp'd, Would seem hyperboles. At this fusty stuff The large Achilles, on his press'd bed lolling, From his deep chest laughs out a loud applause; Cries ‘Excellent! 'Tis Agamemnon right! Now play me Nestor; hem, and stroke thy beard, As he being drest to some oration.' That's done-as near as the extremest ends Of parallels, as like as Vulcan and his wife; Yet god Achilles still cries ‘Excellent! 'Tis Nestor right. Now play him me, Patroclus, Arming to answer in a night alarm.' And then, forsooth, the faint defects of age Must be the scene of mirth: to cough and spit And, with a palsy fumbling on his gorget, Shake in and out the rivet. And at this sport Sir Valour dies; cries ‘O, enough, Patroclus; Or give me ribs of steel! I shall split all In pleasure of my spleen.' And in this fashion All our abilities, gifts, natures, shapes, Severals and generals of grace exact, Achievements, plots, orders, preventions, Excitements to the field or speech for truce, Success or loss, what is or is not, serves As stuff for these two to make paradoxes.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: And in the imitation of these twain- Who, as Ulysses says, opinion crowns With an imperial voice-many are infect. Ajax is grown self-will'd and bears his head In such a rein, in full as proud a place As broad Achilles; keeps his tent like him; Makes factious feasts; rails on our state of war Bold as an oracle, and sets Thersites, A slave whose gall coins slanders like a mint, To match us in comparisons with dirt, To weaken and discredit our exposure, How rank soever rounded in with danger.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: They tax our policy and call it cowardice, Count wisdom as no member of the war, Forestall prescience, and esteem no act But that of hand. The still and mental parts That do contrive how many hands shall strike When fitness calls them on, and know, by measure Of their observant toil, the enemies' weight- Why, this hath not a finger's dignity: They call this bed-work, mapp'ry, closet-war; So that the ram that batters down the wall, For the great swinge and rudeness of his poise, They place before his hand that made the engine, Or those that with the fineness of their souls By reason guide his execution.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Let this be granted, and Achilles' horse Makes many Thetis' sons.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: What trumpet? Look, Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: From Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: What would you fore our tent?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Is this great Agamemnon's tent, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Even this.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: May one that is a herald and a prince Do a fair message to his kingly eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: With surety stronger than Achilles' arm Fore all the Greekish heads, which with one voice Call Agamemnon head and general.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Fair leave and large security. How may A stranger to those most imperial looks Know them from eyes of other mortals?

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: How?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Ay; I ask, that I might waken reverence, And bid the cheek be ready with a blush Modest as morning when she coldly eyes The youthful Phoebus. Which is that god in office, guiding men? Which is the high and mighty Agamemnon?

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: This Trojan scorns us, or the men of Troy Are ceremonious courtiers.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Courtiers as free, as debonair, unarm'd, As bending angels; that's their fame in peace. But when they would seem soldiers, they have galls, Good arms, strong joints, true swords; and, Jove's accord, Nothing so full of heart. But peace, Aeneas, Peace, Trojan; lay thy finger on thy lips. The worthiness of praise distains his worth, If that the prais'd himself bring the praise forth; But what the repining enemy commends, That breath fame blows; that praise, sole pure, transcends.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Sir, you of Troy, call you yourself Aeneas?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Ay, Greek, that is my name.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: What's your affairs, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Sir, pardon; 'tis for Agamemnon's ears.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: He hears naught privately that comes from Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Nor I from Troy come not to whisper with him; I bring a trumpet to awake his ear, To set his sense on the attentive bent, And then to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Speak frankly as the wind; It is not Agamemnon's sleeping hour. That thou shalt know, Trojan, he is awake, He tells thee so himself.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Trumpet, blow loud, Send thy brass voice through all these lazy tents; And every Greek of mettle, let him know What Troy means fairly shall be spoke aloud. We have, great Agamemnon, here in Troy A prince called Hector-Priam is his father- Who in this dull and long-continued truce Is resty grown; he bade me take a trumpet And to this purpose speak: Kings, princes, lords! If there be one among the fair'st of Greece That holds his honour higher than his ease, That feeds his praise more than he fears his peril, That knows his valour and knows not his fear, That loves his mistress more than in confession With truant vows to her own lips he loves, And dare avow her beauty and her worth In other arms than hers-to him this challenge. Hector, in view of Trojans and of Greeks, Shall make it good or do his best to do it: He hath a lady wiser, fairer, truer, Than ever Greek did couple in his arms; And will tomorrow with his trumpet call Mid-way between your tents and walls of Troy To rouse a Grecian that is true in love. If any come, Hector shall honour him; If none, he'll say in Troy, when he retires, The Grecian dames are sunburnt and not worth The splinter of a lance. Even so much.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: This shall be told our lovers, Lord Aeneas. If none of them have soul in such a kind, We left them all at home. But we are soldiers; And may that soldier a mere recreant prove That means not, hath not, or is not in love. If then one is, or hath, or means to be, That one meets Hector; if none else, I am he.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Tell him of Nestor, one that was a man When Hector's grandsire suck'd. He is old now; But if there be not in our Grecian host A noble man that hath one spark of fire To answer for his love, tell him from me I'll hide my silver beard in a gold beaver, And in my vambrace put this wither'd brawns, And meeting him, will tell him that my lady Was fairer than his grandam, and as chaste As may be in the world. His youth in flood, I'll prove this troth with my three drops of blood.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Now heavens forfend such scarcity of youth!

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Fair Lord Aeneas, let me touch your hand; To our pavilion shall I lead you, sir. Achilles shall have word of this intent; So shall each lord of Greece, from tent to tent. Yourself shall feast with us before you go, And find the welcome of a noble foe.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Nestor!

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: What says Ulysses?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: I have a young conception in my brain; Be you my time to bring it to some shape.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: What is't?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: This 'tis: Blunt wedges rive hard knots. The seeded pride That hath to this maturity blown up In rank Achilles must or now be cropp'd Or, shedding, breed a nursery of like evil To overbulk us all.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Well, and how?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: This challenge that the gallant Hector sends, However it is spread in general name, Relates in purpose only to Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: True. The purpose is perspicuous even as substance Whose grossness little characters sum up; And, in the publication, make no strain But that Achilles, were his brain as barren As banks of Libya-though, Apollo knows, 'Tis dry enough-will with great speed of judgement, Ay, with celerity, find Hector's purpose Pointing on him.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: And wake him to the answer, think you?

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Why, 'tis most meet. Who may you else oppose That can from Hector bring those honours off, If not Achilles? Though 't be a sportful combat, Yet in this trial much opinion dwells For here the Trojans taste our dear'st repute With their fin'st palate; and trust to me, Ulysses, Our imputation shall be oddly pois'd In this vile action; for the success, Although particular, shall give a scantling Of good or bad unto the general; And in such indexes, although small pricks To their subsequent volumes, there is seen The baby figure of the giant mass Of things to come at large. It is suppos'd He that meets Hector issues from our choice; And choice, being mutual act of all our souls, Makes merit her election, and doth boil, As 'twere from forth us all, a man distill'd Out of our virtues; who miscarrying, What heart receives from hence a conquering part, To steel a strong opinion to themselves? Which entertain'd, limbs are his instruments, In no less working than are swords and bows Directive by the limbs.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Give pardon to my speech. Therefore 'tis meet Achilles meet not Hector. Let us, like merchants, First show foul wares, and think perchance they'll sell; If not, the lustre of the better shall exceed By showing the worse first. Do not consent That ever Hector and Achilles meet; For both our honour and our shame in this Are dogg'd with two strange followers.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: I see them not with my old eyes. What are they?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: What glory our Achilles shares from Hector, Were he not proud, we all should share with him; But he already is too insolent; And it were better parch in Afric sun Than in the pride and salt scorn of his eyes, Should he scape Hector fair. If he were foil'd, Why, then we do our main opinion crush In taint of our best man. No, make a lott'ry; And, by device, let blockish Ajax draw The sort to fight with Hector. Among ourselves Give him allowance for the better man; For that will physic the great Myrmidon, Who broils in loud applause, and make him fall His crest, that prouder than blue Iris bends. If the dull brainless Ajax come safe off, We'll dress him up in voices; if he fail, Yet go we under our opinion still That we have better men. But, hit or miss, Our project's life this shape of sense assumes- Ajax employ'd plucks down Achilles' plumes.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Now, Ulysses, I begin to relish thy advice; And I will give a taste thereof forthwith To Agamemnon. Go we to him straight. Two curs shall tame each other: pride alone Must tarre the mastiffs on, as 'twere their bone.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Thersites!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Agamemnon-how if he had boils, full, all over, generally?

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Thersites!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: And those boils did run-say so. Did not the general run then? Were not that a botchy core?

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Dog!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Then there would come some matter from him; I see none now.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Thou bitch-wolf's son, canst thou not hear? Feel, then.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: The plague of Greece upon thee, thou mongrel beef-witted lord!

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Speak, then, thou unsalted leaven, speak. I will beat thee into handsomeness.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I shall sooner rail thee into wit and holiness; but I think thy horse will sooner con an oration than thou learn a prayer without book. Thou canst strike, canst thou? A red murrain o' thy jade's tricks!

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Toadstool, learn me the proclamation.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Dost thou think I have no sense, thou strikest me thus?

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: The proclamation!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Thou art proclaim'd fool, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Do not, porpentine, do not; my fingers itch.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I would thou didst itch from head to foot and I had the scratching of thee; I would make thee the loathsomest scab in Greece. When thou art forth in the incursions, thou strikest as slow as another.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I say, the proclamation.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Thou grumblest and railest every hour on Achilles; and thou art as full of envy at his greatness as Cerberus is at Proserpina's beauty-ay, that thou bark'st at him.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Mistress Thersites!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Thou shouldst strike him.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Cobloaf!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: He would pun thee into shivers with his fist, as a sailor breaks a biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: You whoreson cur!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Do, do.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Thou stool for a witch!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Ay, do, do; thou sodden-witted lord! Thou hast no more brain than I have in mine elbows; an asinico may tutor thee. You scurvy valiant ass! Thou art here but to thrash Trojans, and thou art bought and sold among those of any wit like a barbarian slave. If thou use to beat me, I will begin at thy heel and tell what thou art by inches, thou thing of no bowels, thou!

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: You dog!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: You scurvy lord!

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: You cur!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Mars his idiot! Do, rudeness; do, camel; do, do.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Why, how now, Ajax! Wherefore do ye thus? How now, Thersites! What's the matter, man?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: You see him there, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Ay; what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Nay, look upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: So I do. What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Nay, but regard him well.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Well! why, so I do.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: But yet you look not well upon him; for whosomever you take him to be, he is Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I know that, fool.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Ay, but that fool knows not himself.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Therefore I beat thee.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Lo, lo, lo, lo, what modicums of wit he utters! His evasions have ears thus long. I have bobb'd his brain more than he has beat my bones. I will buy nine sparrows for a penny, and his pia mater is not worth the ninth part of a sparrow. This lord, Achilles-Ajax, who wears his wit in his belly and his guts in his head-I'll tell you what I say of him.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I say this Ajax-

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Nay, good Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Has not so much wit-

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Nay, I must hold you.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: As will stop the eye of Helen's needle, for whom he comes to fight.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Peace, fool.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I would have peace and quietness, but the fool will not- he there; that he; look you there.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: O thou damned cur! I shall-

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Will you set your wit to a fool's?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: No, I warrant you, the fool's will shame it.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Good words, Thersites.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What's the quarrel?

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I bade the vile owl go learn me the tenour of the proclamation, and he rails upon me.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I serve thee not.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Well, go to, go to.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I serve here voluntary.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Your last service was suff'rance; 'twas not voluntary. No man is beaten voluntary. Ajax was here the voluntary, and you as under an impress.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: E'en so; a great deal of your wit too lies in your sinews, or else there be liars. Hector shall have a great catch and knock out either of your brains: a' were as good crack a fusty nut with no kernel.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What, with me too, Thersites?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: There's Ulysses and old Nestor-whose wit was mouldy ere your grandsires had nails on their toes-yoke you like draught oxen, and make you plough up the wars.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What, what?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Yes, good sooth. To Achilles, to Ajax, to-

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I shall cut out your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: 'Tis no matter; I shall speak as much as thou afterwards.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: No more words, Thersites; peace!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I will hold my peace when Achilles' brach bids me, shall I?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: There's for you, Patroclus.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I will see you hang'd like clotpoles ere I come any more to your tents. I will keep where there is wit stirring, and leave the faction of fools.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: A good riddance.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Marry, this, sir, is proclaim'd through all our host, That Hector, by the fifth hour of the sun, Will with a trumpet 'twixt our tents and Troy, Tomorrow morning, call some knight to arms That hath a stomach; and such a one that dare Maintain I know not what; 'tis trash. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Farewell. Who shall answer him?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I know not; 'tis put to lott'ry, otherwise, He knew his man.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: O, meaning you? I will go learn more of it.

dialogues.speaker: Priam
dialogues.line: After so many hours, lives, speeches spent, Thus once again says Nestor from the Greeks: ‘Deliver Helen, and all damage else- As honour, loss of time, travail, expense, Wounds, friends, and what else dear that is consum'd In hot digestion of this cormorant war- Shall be struck off.' Hector, what say you to't?

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Though no man lesser fears the Greeks than I, As far as toucheth my particular, Yet, dread Priam, There is no lady of more softer bowels, More spongy to suck in the sense of fear, More ready to cry out ‘Who knows what follows?' Than Hector is. The wound of peace is surety, Surety secure; but modest doubt is call'd The beacon of the wise, the tent that searches To th' bottom of the worst. Let Helen go. Since the first sword was drawn about this question, Every tithe soul 'mongst many thousand dismes Hath been as dear as Helen-I mean, of ours. If we have lost so many tenths of ours To guard a thing not ours, nor worth to us, Had it our name, the value of one ten, What merit's in that reason which denies The yielding of her up?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Fie, fie, my brother! Weigh you the worth and honour of a king, So great as our dread father's, in a scale Of common ounces? Will you with counters sum The past-proportion of his infinite, And buckle in a waist most fathomless With spans and inches so diminutive As fears and reasons? Fie, for godly shame!

dialogues.speaker: Helenus
dialogues.line: No marvel though you bite so sharp of reasons, You are so empty of them. Should not our father Bear the great sway of his affairs with reason, Because your speech hath none that tells him so?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: You are for dreams and slumbers, brother priest; You fur your gloves with reason. Here are your reasons: You know an enemy intends you harm; You know a sword employ'd is perilous, And reason flies the object of all harm. Who marvels, then, when Helenus beholds A Grecian and his sword, if he do set The very wings of reason to his heels And fly like chidden Mercury from Jove, Or like a star disorb'd? Nay, if we talk of reason, Let's shut our gates and sleep. Manhood and honour Should have hare hearts, would they but fat their thoughts With this cramm'd reason. Reason and respect Make livers pale and lustihood deject.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Brother, she is not worth what she doth cost the keeping.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: What's aught but as 'tis valued?

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: But value dwells not in particular will: It holds his estimate and dignity As well wherein 'tis precious of itself As in the prizer. 'Tis mad idolatry To make the service greater than the god, And the will dotes that is attributive To what infectiously itself affects, Without some image of th'affected merit.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I take today a wife, and my election Is led on in the conduct of my will; My will enkindled by mine eyes and ears, Two traded pilots 'twixt the dangerous shores Of will and judgement: how may I avoid, Although my will distaste what it elected, The wife I chose? There can be no evasion To blench from this and to stand firm by honour. We turn not back the silks upon the merchant When we have soil'd them; nor the remainder viands We do not throw in unrespective sieve, Because we now are full. It was thought meet Paris should do some vengeance on the Greeks; Your breath with full consent bellied his sails; The seas and winds, old wranglers, took a truce, And did him service. He touch'd the ports desir'd; And for an old aunt whom the Greeks held captive He brought a Grecian queen, whose youth and freshness Wrinkles Apollo's, and makes stale the morning. Why keep we her? The Grecians keep our aunt. Is she worth keeping? Why, she is a pearl Whose price hath launch'd above a thousand ships, And turn'd crown'd kings to merchants. If you'll avouch 'twas wisdom Paris went- As you must needs, for you all cried ‘Go, go'- If you'll confess he brought home worthy prize- As you must needs, for you all clapp'd your hands, And cried ‘Inestimable!'-why do you now The issue of your proper wisdoms rate, And do a deed that never Fortune did- Beggar the estimation which you priz'd Richer than sea and land? O theft most base, That we have stol'n what we do fear to keep! But thieves unworthy of a thing so stol'n That in their country did them that disgrace We fear to warrant in our native place!

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: Cry, Trojans, cry.

dialogues.speaker: Priam
dialogues.line: What noise, what shriek is this?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: 'Tis our mad sister; I do know her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: Cry, Trojans.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: It is Cassandra.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: Cry, Trojans, cry. Lend me ten thousand eyes, And I will fill them with prophetic tears.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Peace, sister, peace.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: Virgins and boys, mid-age and wrinkled eld, Soft infancy, that nothing canst but cry, Add to my clamours. Let us pay betimes A moiety of that mass of moan to come. Cry, Trojans, cry. Practise your eyes with tears. Troy must not be, nor goodly Ilion stand; Our firebrand brother, Paris, burns us all. Cry, Trojans, cry, A Helen and a woe! Cry, cry. Troy burns, or else let Helen go.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Now, youthful Troilus, do not these high strains Of divination in our sister work Some touches of remorse? Or is your blood So madly hot, that no discourse of reason, Nor fear of bad success in a bad cause, Can qualify the same?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Why, brother Hector, We may not think the justness of each act Such and no other than event doth form it; Nor once deject the courage of our minds Because Cassandra's mad. Her brain-sick raptures Cannot distaste the goodness of a quarrel Which hath our several honours all engag'd To make it gracious. For my private part, I am no more touch'd than all Priam's sons; And Jove forbid there should be done amongst us Such things as might offend the weakest spleen To fight for and maintain.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Else might the world convince of levity As well my undertakings as your counsels; But I attest the gods, your full consent Gave wings to my propension, and cut off All fears attending on so dire a project. For what, alas, can these my single arms? What propugnation is in one man's valour To stand the push and enmity of those This quarrel would excite? Yet I protest, Were I alone to pass the difficulties, And had as ample power as I have will, Paris should ne'er retract what he hath done, Nor faint in the pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Priam
dialogues.line: Paris, you speak Like one besotted on your sweet delights. You have the honey still, but these the gall; So to be valiant is no praise at all.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Sir, I propose not merely to myself The pleasures such a beauty brings with it; But I would have the soil of her fair rape Wip'd off in honourable keeping her. What treason were it to the ransack'd queen, Disgrace to your great worths, and shame to me, Now to deliver her possession up On terms of base compulsion! Can it be, That so degenerate a strain as this Should once set footing in your generous bosoms? There's not the meanest spirit on our party Without a heart to dare or sword to draw When Helen is defended; nor none so noble Whose life were ill bestow'd or death unfam'd, Where Helen is the subject. Then, I say, Well may we fight for her whom we know well The world's large spaces cannot parallel.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Paris and Troilus, you have both said well; And on the cause and question now in hand Have gloz'd, but superficially; not much Unlike young men, whom Aristotle thought Unfit to hear moral philosophy. The reasons you allege do more conduce To the hot passion of distemp'red blood Than to make up a free determination 'Twixt right and wrong; for pleasure and revenge Have ears more deaf than adders to the voice Of any true decision. Nature craves All dues be rend'red to their owners. Now, What nearer debt in all humanity Than wife is to the husband? If this law Of nature be corrupted through affection; And that great minds, of partial indulgence To their benumbed wills, resist the same; There is a law in each well-order'd nation To curb those raging appetites that are Most disobedient and refractory. If Helen, then, be wife to Sparta's king- As it is known she is-these moral laws Of nature and of nations speak aloud To have her back return'd. Thus to persist In doing wrong extenuates not wrong, But makes it much more heavy. Hector's opinion Is this, in way of truth. Yet, ne'ertheless, My spritely brethren, I propend to you In resolution to keep Helen still; For 'tis a cause that hath no mean dependence Upon our joint and several dignities.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Why, there you touch'd the life of our design. Were it not glory that we more affected Than the performance of our heaving spleens, I would not wish a drop of Trojan blood Spent more in her defence. But, worthy Hector, She is a theme of honour and renown, A spur to valiant and magnanimous deeds, Whose present courage may beat down our foes, And fame in time to come canonize us; For I presume brave Hector would not lose So rich advantage of a promis'd glory As smiles upon the forehead of this action For the wide world's revenue.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I am yours, You valiant offspring of great Priamus. I have a roisting challenge sent amongst The dull and factious nobles of the Greeks Will strike amazement to their drowsy spirits. I was advertis'd their great general slept, Whilst emulation in the army crept. This, I presume, will wake him.

scenes.location: The Grecian camp. Before the tent of Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: How now, Thersites! What, lost in the labyrinth of thy fury? Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He beats me, and I rail at him. O worthy satisfaction! Would it were otherwise: that I could beat him, whilst he rail'd at me! ‘Sfoot, I'll learn to conjure and raise devils, but I'll see some issue of my spiteful execrations. Then there's Achilles, a rare engineer! If Troy be not taken till these two undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus, forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods, and, Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy caduceus, if ye take not that little little less than little wit from them that they have! which short-arm'd ignorance itself knows is so abundant scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly from a spider without drawing their massy irons and cutting the web. After this, the vengeance on the whole camp! or, rather, the Neapolitan bone-ache! for that, methinks, is the curse depending on those that war for a placket. I have said my prayers; and devil Envy say ‘Amen.' What ho! my Lord Achilles!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites, come in and rail.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: If I could a' rememb'red a gilt counterfeit, thou wouldst not have slipp'd out of my contemplation; but it is no matter; thyself upon thyself! The common curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in great revenue! Heaven bless thee from a tutor, and discipline come not near thee! Let thy blood be thy direction till thy death. Then if she that lays thee out says thou art a fair corse, I'll be sworn and sworn upon't she never shrouded any but lazars. Amen. Where's Achilles?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: What, art thou devout? Wast thou in prayer?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Ay, the heavens hear me!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Thersites, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Where, where? O, where? Art thou come? Why, my cheese, my digestion, why hast thou not served thyself in to my table so many meals? Come, what's Agamemnon?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Thy commander, Achilles. Then tell me, Patroclus, what's Achilles?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Thy lord, Thersites. Then tell me, I pray thee, what's Thersites?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Thy knower, Patroclus. Then tell me, Patroclus, what art thou?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Thou must tell that knowest.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: O, tell, tell,

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I'll decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands Achilles; Achilles is my lord; I am Patroclus' knower; and Patroclus is a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: You rascal!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Peace, fool! I have not done.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: He is a privileg'd man. Proceed, Thersites.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Agamemnon is a fool; Achilles is a fool; Thersites is a fool; and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Derive this; come.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles; Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemnon; Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool; and this Patroclus is a fool positive.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Why am I a fool?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Make that demand of the Creator. It suffices me thou art. Look you, who comes here?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Come, Patroclus, I'll speak with nobody. Come in with me, Thersites.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Here is such patchery, such juggling, and such knavery. All the argument is a whore and a cuckold-a good quarrel to draw emulous factions and bleed to death upon. Now the dry serpigo on the subject, and war and lechery confound all!

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Where is Achilles?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Within his tent; but ill-dispos'd, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Let it be known to him that we are here. He shent our messengers; and we lay by Our appertainings, visiting of him. Let him be told so; lest, perchance, he think We dare not move the question of our place Or know not what we are.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: I shall say so to him.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: We saw him at the opening of his tent. He is not sick.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart. You may call it melancholy, if you will favour the man; but, by my head, 'tis pride. But why, why? Let him show us a cause. A word, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Who, Thersites?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: He.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: No; you see he is his argument that has his argument, Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: All the better; their fraction is more our wish than their faction. But it was a strong composure a fool could disunite!

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily untie. Here comes Patroclus.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: No Achilles with him.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy; his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Achilles bids me say he is much sorry If any thing more than your sport and pleasure Did move your greatness and this noble state To call upon him; he hopes it is no other But for your health and your digestion sake, An after-dinner's breath.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Hear you, Patroclus. We are too well acquainted with these answers; But his evasion, wing'd thus swift with scorn, Cannot outfly our apprehensions. Much attribute he hath, and much the reason Why we ascribe it to him. Yet all his virtues, Not virtuously on his own part beheld, Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss; Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish, Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin If you do say we think him over-proud And under-honest, in self-assumption greater Than in the note of judgement; and worthier than himself Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on, Disguise the holy strength of their command, And underwrite in an observing kind His humorous predominance; yea, watch His course and time, his ebbs and flows, as if The passage and whole stream of this commencement Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add That if he overhold his price so much We'll none of him, but let him, like an engine Not portable, lie under this report: Bring action hither; this cannot go to war. A stirring dwarf we do allowance give Before a sleeping giant. Tell him so.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: I shall, and bring his answer presently.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: In second voice we'll not be satisfied; We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: What is he more than another?

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: No more than what he thinks he is.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a better man than I am?

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: No question.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Will you subscribe his thought and say he is?

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether more tractable.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I know not what pride is.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the fairer. He that is proud eats up himself. Pride is his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle; and whatever praises itself but in the deed devours the deed in the praise.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I do hate a proud man as I do hate the engend'ring of toads.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: And yet he loves himself: is't not strange?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Achilles will not to the field tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: What's his excuse?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: He doth rely on none; But carries on the stream of his dispose, Without observance or respect of any, In will peculiar and in self-admission.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Why will he not, upon our fair request, Untent his person and share th'air with us?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Things small as nothing, for request's sake only, He makes important; possess'd he is with greatness, And speaks not to himself but with a pride That quarrels at self-breath. Imagin'd worth Holds in his blood such swol'n and hot discourse That 'twixt his mental and his active parts Kingdom'd Achilles in commotion rages, And batters down himself. What should I say? He is so plaguy proud that the death tokens of it Cry ‘No recovery.'

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Let Ajax go to him. Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent. 'Tis said he holds you well; and will be led At your request a little from himself.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: O Agamemnon, let it not be so! We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes When they go from Achilles. Shall the proud lord That bastes his arrogance with his own seam And never suffers matter of the world And ruminate himself-shall he be worshipp'd Of that we hold an idol more than he? No, this thrice worthy and right valiant lord Shall not so stale his palm, nobly acquir'd, Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit, As amply titled as Achilles is, By going to Achilles. That were to enlard his fat-already pride, And add more coals to Cancer when he burns With entertaining great Hyperion. This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid, And say in thunder ‘Achilles go to him.'

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: O, this is well! He rubs the vein of him.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: And how his silence drinks up this applause!

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: If I go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the face.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: O, no, you shall not go.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: An a' be proud with me I'll pheeze his pride. Let me go to him.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: A paltry, insolent fellow!

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: How he describes himself!

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Can he not be sociable?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: The raven chides blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I'll let his humours blood.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: And all men were o' my mind-

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Wit would be out of fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: A' should not bear it so, a' should eat's words first. Shall pride carry it?

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: And 'twould, you'd carry half.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: A' would have ten shares.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I will knead him, I'll make him supple.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: He's not yet through warm. Force him with praises; pour in, pour in; his ambition is dry.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Our noble general, do not do so.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Why 'tis this naming of him does him harm. Here is a man-but 'tis before his face; I will be silent.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Wherefore should you so? He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: A whoreson dog, that shall palter with us thus! Would he were a Trojan!

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: What a vice were it in Ajax now-

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: If he were proud.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Or covetous of praise.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Ay, or surly borne.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Or strange, or self-affected.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure. Praise him that gat thee, she that gave thee suck; Fam'd be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature Thrice fam'd beyond, beyond all erudition; But he that disciplin'd thine arms to fight- Let Mars divide eternity in twain And give him half; and, for thy vigour, Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield To sinewy Ajax. I will not praise thy wisdom, Which, like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines Thy spacious and dilated parts. Here's Nestor, Instructed by the antiquary times- He must, he is, he cannot but be wise; But pardon, father Nestor, were your days As green as Ajax' and your brain so temper'd, You should not have the eminence of him, But be as Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Shall I call you father?

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Ay, my good son.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Be rul'd by him, Lord Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles Keeps thicket. Please it our great general To call together all his state of war; Fresh kings are come to Troy. Tomorrow We must with all our main of power stand fast; And here's a lord-come knights from east to west And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep. Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Friend, you-pray you, a word. Do you not follow the young Lord Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, when he goes before me.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You depend upon him, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Sir, I do depend upon the Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You depend upon a notable gentleman; I must needs praise him.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: The Lord be praised!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You know me, do you not?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Faith, sir, superficially.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Friend, know me better: I am the Lord Pandarus.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I hope I shall know your honour better.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I do desire it.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: You are in the state of grace?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Grace? Not so, friend; honour and lordship are my titles. What music is this?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I do but partly know, sir; it is music in parts.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Know you the musicians?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Wholly, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Who play they to?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: To the hearers, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: At whose pleasure, friend?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: At mine, sir, and theirs that love music.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Command, I mean, friend.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Who shall I command, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Friend, we understand not one another: I am too courtly, and thou art too cunning. At whose request do these men play?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: That's to't, indeed, sir. Marry, sir, at the request of Paris my lord, who is there in person; with him the mortal Venus, the heart-blood of beauty, love's invisible soul-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Who, my cousin, Cressida?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: No, sir, Helen. Could not you find out that by her attributes?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: It should seem, fellow, that thou hast not seen the Lady Cressida. I come to speak with Paris from the Prince Troilus; I will make a complimental assault upon him, for my business seethes.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Sodden business! There's a stew'd phrase indeed!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Fair be to you, my lord, and to all this fair company! Fair desires, in all fair measure, fairly guide them-especially to you, fair queen! Fair thoughts be your fair pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Dear lord, you are full of fair words.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You speak your fair pleasure, sweet queen. Fair prince, here is good broken music.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: You have broke it, cousin; and by my life, you shall make it whole again; you shall piece it out with a piece of your performance.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: He is full of harmony.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Truly, lady, no.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: O, sir-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Rude, in sooth; in good sooth, very rude.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Well said, my lord. Well, you say so in fits.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I have business to my lord, dear queen. My lord, will you vouchsafe me a word?

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Nay, this shall not hedge us out. We'll hear you sing, certainly-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Well sweet queen, you are pleasant with me. But, marry, thus, my lord: my dear lord and most esteemed friend, your brother Troilus-

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: My Lord Pandarus, honey-sweet lord-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Go to, sweet queen, go to-commends himself most affectionately to you-

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: You shall not bob us out of our melody. If you do, our melancholy upon your head!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Sweet queen, sweet queen; that's a sweet queen, i' faith.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: And to make a sweet lady sad is a sour offence.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
