dialogues.line: Nay, that shall not serve your turn; that shall it not, in truth, la. Nay, I care not for such words; no, no.-And, my lord, he desires you that, if the King call for him at supper, you will make his excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: My Lord Pandarus!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What says my sweet queen, my very very sweet queen?

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: What exploit's in hand? Where sups he tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Nay, but, my lord-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What says my sweet queen?-My cousin will fall out with you.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: You must not know where he sups.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: I'll lay my life, with my disposer Cressida.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: No, no, no such matter; you are wide. Come, your disposer is sick.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Well, I'll make's excuse.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ay, good my lord. Why should you say Cressida? No, your poor disposer's sick.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: I spy.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: You spy! What do you spy?-Come, give me an instrument. Now, sweet queen.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Why, this is kindly done.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: My niece is horribly in love with a thing you have, sweet queen.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: She shall have it, my lord, if it be not my Lord Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: He? No, she'll none of him; they two are twain.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Falling in, after falling out, may make them three.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Come, come. I'll hear no more of this; I'll sing you a song now.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, prithee now. By my troth, sweet lord, thou hast a fine forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ay, you may, you may.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Let thy song be love. This love will undo us all. O Cupid, Cupid, Cupid!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Love! Ay, that it shall, i' faith.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Ay, good now, love, love, nothing but love.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: In good troth, it begins so. _Love, love, nothing but love, still love, still more! For, oh, love's bow Shoots buck and doe; The shaft confounds Not that it wounds, But tickles still the sore. These lovers cry, O ho, they die! Yet that which seems the wound to kill Doth turn O ho! to ha! ha! he! So dying love lives still. O ho! a while, but ha! ha! ha! O ho! groans out for ha! ha! ha!-hey ho!_

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: In love, i' faith, to the very tip of the nose.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: He eats nothing but doves, love; and that breeds hot blood, and hot blood begets hot thoughts, and hot thoughts beget hot deeds, and hot deeds is love.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Is this the generation of love: hot blood, hot thoughts, and hot deeds? Why, they are vipers. Is love a generation of vipers? Sweet lord, who's a-field today?

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Hector, Deiphobus, Helenus, Antenor, and all the gallantry of Troy. I would fain have arm'd today, but my Nell would not have it so. How chance my brother Troilus went not?

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: He hangs the lip at something. You know all, Lord Pandarus.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Not I, honey-sweet queen. I long to hear how they spend today. You'll remember your brother's excuse?

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: To a hair.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Farewell, sweet queen.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: Commend me to your niece.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I will, sweet queen.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: They're come from the field. Let us to Priam's hall To greet the warriors. Sweet Helen, I must woo you To help unarm our Hector. His stubborn buckles, With these your white enchanting fingers touch'd, Shall more obey than to the edge of steel Or force of Greekish sinews; you shall do more Than all the island kings-disarm great Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Helen
dialogues.line: 'Twill make us proud to be his servant, Paris; Yea, what he shall receive of us in duty Gives us more palm in beauty than we have, Yea, overshines ourself.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Sweet, above thought I love thee.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: How now! Where's thy master? At my cousin Cressida's?

dialogues.speaker: Boy
dialogues.line: No, sir; he stays for you to conduct him thither.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: O, here he comes. How now, how now?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Sirrah, walk off.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Have you seen my cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: No, Pandarus. I stalk about her door Like a strange soul upon the Stygian banks Staying for waftage. O, be thou my Charon, And give me swift transportance to these fields Where I may wallow in the lily beds Propos'd for the deserver! O gentle Pandar, from Cupid's shoulder pluck his painted wings, and fly with me to Cressid!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Walk here i' th' orchard, I'll bring her straight.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I am giddy; expectation whirls me round. Th'imaginary relish is so sweet That it enchants my sense; what will it be When that the wat'ry palate tastes indeed Love's thrice-repured nectar? Death, I fear me; Sounding destruction; or some joy too fine, Too subtle-potent, tun'd too sharp in sweetness, For the capacity of my ruder powers. I fear it much; and I do fear besides That I shall lose distinction in my joys; As doth a battle, when they charge on heaps The enemy flying.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: She's making her ready, she'll come straight; you must be witty now. She does so blush, and fetches her wind so short, as if she were fray'd with a sprite. I'll fetch her. It is the prettiest villain; she fetches her breath as short as a new-ta'en sparrow.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Even such a passion doth embrace my bosom. My heart beats thicker than a feverous pulse, And all my powers do their bestowing lose, Like vassalage at unawares encount'ring The eye of majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Come, come, what need you blush? Shame's a baby. Here she is now; swear the oaths now to her that you have sworn to me.-What, are you gone again? You must be watch'd ere you be made tame, must you? Come your ways, come your ways; and you draw backward, we'll put you i' th' fills. Why do you not speak to her? Come, draw this curtain and let's see your picture. Alas the day, how loath you are to offend daylight! And 'twere dark, you'd close sooner. So, so; rub on, and kiss the mistress. How now, a kiss in fee-farm! Build there, carpenter; the air is sweet. Nay, you shall fight your hearts out ere I part you. The falcon as the tercel, for all the ducks i' th' river. Go to, go to.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: You have bereft me of all words, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Words pay no debts, give her deeds; but she'll bereave you o' th' deeds too, if she call your activity in question. What, billing again? Here's ‘In witness whereof the parties interchangeably.' Come in, come in; I'll go get a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Will you walk in, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O Cressid, how often have I wish'd me thus!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Wish'd, my lord! The gods grant-O my lord!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: What should they grant? What makes this pretty abruption? What too curious dreg espies my sweet lady in the fountain of our love?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: More dregs than water, if my fears have eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Fears make devils of cherubins; they never see truly.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Blind fear, that seeing reason leads, finds safer footing than blind reason stumbling without fear. To fear the worst oft cures the worse.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O, let my lady apprehend no fear! In all Cupid's pageant there is presented no monster.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Nor nothing monstrous neither?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Nothing, but our undertakings when we vow to weep seas, live in fire, eat rocks, tame tigers; thinking it harder for our mistress to devise imposition enough than for us to undergo any difficulty imposed. This is the monstruosity in love, lady, that the will is infinite, and the execution confin'd; that the desire is boundless, and the act a slave to limit.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: They say all lovers swear more performance than they are able, and yet reserve an ability that they never perform; vowing more than the perfection of ten, and discharging less than the tenth part of one. They that have the voice of lions and the act of hares, are they not monsters?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Are there such? Such are not we. Praise us as we are tasted, allow us as we prove; our head shall go bare till merit crown it. No perfection in reversion shall have a praise in present. We will not name desert before his birth; and, being born, his addition shall be humble. Few words to fair faith: Troilus shall be such to Cressid as what envy can say worst shall be a mock for his truth; and what truth can speak truest not truer than Troilus.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Will you walk in, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What, blushing still? Have you not done talking yet?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Well, uncle, what folly I commit, I dedicate to you.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: I thank you for that; if my lord get a boy of you, you'll give him me. Be true to my lord; if he flinch, chide me for it.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: You know now your hostages: your uncle's word and my firm faith.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll give my word for her too: our kindred, though they be long ere they are wooed, they are constant being won; they are burs, I can tell you; they'll stick where they are thrown.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Boldness comes to me now and brings me heart. Prince Troilus, I have lov'd you night and day For many weary months.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Why was my Cressid then so hard to win?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Hard to seem won; but I was won, my lord, With the first glance that ever-pardon me. If I confess much, you will play the tyrant. I love you now; but till now not so much But I might master it. In faith, I lie; My thoughts were like unbridled children, grown Too headstrong for their mother. See, we fools! Why have I blabb'd? Who shall be true to us, When we are so unsecret to ourselves? But, though I lov'd you well, I woo'd you not; And yet, good faith, I wish'd myself a man, Or that we women had men's privilege Of speaking first. Sweet, bid me hold my tongue, For in this rapture I shall surely speak The thing I shall repent. See, see, your silence, Cunning in dumbness, from my weakness draws My very soul of counsel. Stop my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: And shall, albeit sweet music issues thence.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Pretty, i' faith.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: My lord, I do beseech you, pardon me; 'Twas not my purpose thus to beg a kiss. I am asham'd. O heavens! what have I done? For this time will I take my leave, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Your leave, sweet Cressid!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Leave! And you take leave till tomorrow morning-

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Pray you, content you.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: What offends you, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Sir, mine own company.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: You cannot shun yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Let me go and try. I have a kind of self resides with you; But an unkind self, that itself will leave To be another's fool. I would be gone. Where is my wit? I know not what I speak.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Well know they what they speak that speak so wisely.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Perchance, my lord, I show more craft than love; And fell so roundly to a large confession To angle for your thoughts; but you are wise- Or else you love not; for to be wise and love Exceeds man's might; that dwells with gods above.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O that I thought it could be in a woman- As, if it can, I will presume in you- To feed for aye her lamp and flames of love; To keep her constancy in plight and youth, Outliving beauty's outward, with a mind That doth renew swifter than blood decays! Or that persuasion could but thus convince me That my integrity and truth to you Might be affronted with the match and weight Of such a winnowed purity in love. How were I then uplifted! But, alas, I am as true as truth's simplicity, And simpler than the infancy of truth.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: In that I'll war with you.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O virtuous fight, When right with right wars who shall be most right! True swains in love shall in the world to come Approve their truth by Troilus, when their rhymes, Full of protest, of oath, and big compare, Want similes, truth tir'd with iteration- As true as steel, as plantage to the moon, As sun to day, as turtle to her mate, As iron to adamant, as earth to th' centre- Yet, after all comparisons of truth, As truth's authentic author to be cited, ‘As true as Troilus' shall crown up the verse And sanctify the numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Prophet may you be! If I be false, or swerve a hair from truth, When time is old and hath forgot itself, When waterdrops have worn the stones of Troy, And blind oblivion swallow'd cities up, And mighty states characterless are grated To dusty nothing-yet let memory From false to false, among false maids in love, Upbraid my falsehood when th' have said ‘As false As air, as water, wind, or sandy earth, As fox to lamb, or wolf to heifer's calf, Pard to the hind, or stepdame to her son'- Yea, let them say, to stick the heart of falsehood, ‘As false as Cressid.'

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Go to, a bargain made; seal it, seal it; I'll be the witness. Here I hold your hand; here my cousin's. If ever you prove false one to another, since I have taken such pains to bring you together, let all pitiful goers-between be call'd to the world's end after my name-call them all Pandars; let all constant men be Troiluses, all false women Cressids, and all brokers between Pandars. Say ‘Amen.'

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Amen. Whereupon I will show you a chamber and a bed; which bed, because it shall not speak of your pretty encounters, press it to death. Away! And Cupid grant all tongue-tied maidens here, Bed, chamber, pander, to provide this gear!

dialogues.speaker: Calchas
dialogues.line: Now, Princes, for the service I have done, Th'advantage of the time prompts me aloud To call for recompense. Appear it to your mind That, through the sight I bear in things to come, I have abandon'd Troy, left my possession, Incurr'd a traitor's name, expos'd myself From certain and possess'd conveniences To doubtful fortunes, sequest'ring from me all That time, acquaintance, custom, and condition, Made tame and most familiar to my nature; And here, to do you service, am become As new into the world, strange, unacquainted- I do beseech you, as in way of taste, To give me now a little benefit Out of those many regist'red in promise, Which you say live to come in my behalf.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: What wouldst thou of us, Trojan? Make demand.

dialogues.speaker: Calchas
dialogues.line: You have a Trojan prisoner call'd Antenor, Yesterday took; Troy holds him very dear. Oft have you-often have you thanks therefore- Desir'd my Cressid in right great exchange, Whom Troy hath still denied; but this Antenor, I know, is such a wrest in their affairs That their negotiations all must slack Wanting his manage; and they will almost Give us a prince of blood, a son of Priam, In change of him. Let him be sent, great Princes, And he shall buy my daughter; and her presence Shall quite strike off all service I have done In most accepted pain.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Let Diomedes bear him, And bring us Cressid hither. Calchas shall have What he requests of us. Good Diomed, Furnish you fairly for this interchange; Withal, bring word if Hector will tomorrow Be answer'd in his challenge. Ajax is ready.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: This shall I undertake; and 'tis a burden Which I am proud to bear.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Achilles stands i' th'entrance of his tent. Please it our general pass strangely by him, As if he were forgot; and, Princes all, Lay negligent and loose regard upon him. I will come last. 'Tis like he'll question me Why such unplausive eyes are bent, why turn'd on him. If so, I have derision med'cinable To use between your strangeness and his pride, Which his own will shall have desire to drink. It may do good. Pride hath no other glass To show itself but pride; for supple knees Feed arrogance and are the proud man's fees.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: We'll execute your purpose, and put on A form of strangeness as we pass along. So do each lord; and either greet him not, Or else disdainfully, which shall shake him more Than if not look'd on. I will lead the way.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What comes the general to speak with me? You know my mind. I'll fight no more 'gainst Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: What says Achilles? Would he aught with us?

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Would you, my lord, aught with the general?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Nothing, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: The better.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Good day, good day.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: How do you? How do you?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What, does the cuckold scorn me?

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: How now, Patroclus?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Good morrow, Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Ha?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Good morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Ay, and good next day too.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What mean these fellows? Know they not Achilles?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: They pass by strangely. They were us'd to bend, To send their smiles before them to Achilles, To come as humbly as they us'd to creep To holy altars.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What, am I poor of late? 'Tis certain, greatness, once fall'n out with fortune, Must fall out with men too. What the declin'd is, He shall as soon read in the eyes of others As feel in his own fall; for men, like butterflies, Show not their mealy wings but to the summer; And not a man for being simply man Hath any honour, but honour for those honours That are without him, as place, riches, and favour, Prizes of accident, as oft as merit; Which when they fall, as being slippery standers, The love that lean'd on them as slippery too, Doth one pluck down another, and together Die in the fall. But 'tis not so with me: Fortune and I are friends; I do enjoy At ample point all that I did possess Save these men's looks; who do, methinks, find out Something not worth in me such rich beholding As they have often given. Here is Ulysses. I'll interrupt his reading. How now, Ulysses!

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Now, great Thetis' son!

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What are you reading?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: A strange fellow here Writes me that man-how dearly ever parted, How much in having, or without or in- Cannot make boast to have that which he hath, Nor feels not what he owes, but by reflection; As when his virtues shining upon others Heat them, and they retort that heat again To the first giver.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: This is not strange, Ulysses. The beauty that is borne here in the face The bearer knows not, but commends itself To others' eyes; nor doth the eye itself- That most pure spirit of sense-behold itself, Not going from itself; but eye to eye opposed Salutes each other with each other's form; For speculation turns not to itself Till it hath travell'd, and is mirror'd there Where it may see itself. This is not strange at all.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: I do not strain at the position- It is familiar-but at the author's drift; Who, in his circumstance, expressly proves That no man is the lord of anything, Though in and of him there be much consisting, Till he communicate his parts to others; Nor doth he of himself know them for aught Till he behold them formed in the applause Where th'are extended; who, like an arch, reverb'rate The voice again; or, like a gate of steel Fronting the sun, receives and renders back His figure and his heat. I was much rapt in this; And apprehended here immediately Th'unknown Ajax. Heavens, what a man is there! A very horse that has he knows not what! Nature, what things there are Most abject in regard and dear in use! What things again most dear in the esteem And poor in worth! Now shall we see tomorrow- An act that very chance doth throw upon him- Ajax renown'd. O heavens, what some men do, While some men leave to do! How some men creep in skittish Fortune's hall, Whiles others play the idiots in her eyes! How one man eats into another's pride, While pride is fasting in his wantonness! To see these Grecian lords!-why, even already They clap the lubber Ajax on the shoulder, As if his foot were on brave Hector's breast, And great Troy shrieking.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I do believe it; for they pass'd by me As misers do by beggars, neither gave to me Good word nor look. What, are my deeds forgot?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back, Wherein he puts alms for oblivion, A great-siz'd monster of ingratitudes. Those scraps are good deeds past, which are devour'd As fast as they are made, forgot as soon As done. Perseverance, dear my lord, Keeps honour bright. To have done is to hang Quite out of fashion, like a rusty mail In monumental mock'ry. Take the instant way; For honour travels in a strait so narrow- Where one but goes abreast. Keep then the path, For emulation hath a thousand sons That one by one pursue; if you give way, Or hedge aside from the direct forthright, Like to an ent'red tide they all rush by And leave you hindmost; Or, like a gallant horse fall'n in first rank, Lie there for pavement to the abject rear, O'er-run and trampled on. Then what they do in present, Though less than yours in past, must o'ertop yours; For Time is like a fashionable host, That slightly shakes his parting guest by th'hand; And with his arms out-stretch'd, as he would fly, Grasps in the comer. The welcome ever smiles, And farewell goes out sighing. O, let not virtue seek Remuneration for the thing it was; For beauty, wit, High birth, vigour of bone, desert in service, Love, friendship, charity, are subjects all To envious and calumniating Time. One touch of nature makes the whole world kin- That all with one consent praise new-born gauds, Though they are made and moulded of things past, And give to dust that is a little gilt More laud than gilt o'er-dusted. The present eye praises the present object. Then marvel not, thou great and complete man, That all the Greeks begin to worship Ajax, Since things in motion sooner catch the eye Than what stirs not. The cry went once on thee, And still it might, and yet it may again, If thou wouldst not entomb thyself alive And case thy reputation in thy tent, Whose glorious deeds but in these fields of late Made emulous missions 'mongst the gods themselves, And drave great Mars to faction.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Of this my privacy I have strong reasons.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: But 'gainst your privacy The reasons are more potent and heroical. 'Tis known, Achilles, that you are in love With one of Priam's daughters.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Ha! known!

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Is that a wonder? The providence that's in a watchful state Knows almost every grain of Plutus' gold; Finds bottom in th'uncomprehensive deeps; Keeps place with thought, and almost, like the gods, Do thoughts unveil in their dumb cradles. There is a mystery-with whom relation Durst never meddle-in the soul of state, Which hath an operation more divine Than breath or pen can give expressure to. All the commerce that you have had with Troy As perfectly is ours as yours, my lord; And better would it fit Achilles much To throw down Hector than Polyxena. But it must grieve young Pyrrhus now at home, When fame shall in our island sound her trump, And all the Greekish girls shall tripping sing ‘Great Hector's sister did Achilles win; But our great Ajax bravely beat down him.' Farewell, my lord. I as your lover speak. The fool slides o'er the ice that you should break.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: To this effect, Achilles, have I mov'd you. A woman impudent and mannish grown Is not more loath'd than an effeminate man In time of action. I stand condemn'd for this; They think my little stomach to the war And your great love to me restrains you thus. Sweet, rouse yourself; and the weak wanton Cupid Shall from your neck unloose his amorous fold, And, like a dew-drop from the lion's mane, Be shook to air.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Shall Ajax fight with Hector?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Ay, and perhaps receive much honour by him.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I see my reputation is at stake; My fame is shrewdly gor'd.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: O, then, beware: Those wounds heal ill that men do give themselves; Omission to do what is necessary Seals a commission to a blank of danger; And danger, like an ague, subtly taints Even then when they sit idly in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Go call Thersites hither, sweet Patroclus. I'll send the fool to Ajax, and desire him T'invite the Trojan lords, after the combat, To see us here unarm'd. I have a woman's longing, An appetite that I am sick withal, To see great Hector in his weeds of peace; To talk with him, and to behold his visage, Even to my full of view. A labour sav'd!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: A wonder!

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: What?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Ajax goes up and down the field asking for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: He must fight singly tomorrow with Hector, and is so prophetically proud of an heroical cudgelling that he raves in saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: How can that be?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Why, a' stalks up and down like a peacock-a stride and a stand; ruminates like an hostess that hath no arithmetic but her brain to set down her reckoning, bites his lip with a politic regard, as who should say ‘There were wit in this head, and 'twould out'; and so there is; but it lies as coldly in him as fire in a flint, which will not show without knocking. The man's undone for ever; for if Hector break not his neck i' th' combat, he'll break't himself in vainglory. He knows not me. I said ‘Good morrow, Ajax'; and he replies ‘Thanks, Agamemnon.' What think you of this man that takes me for the general? He's grown a very land fish, languageless, a monster. A plague of opinion! A man may wear it on both sides, like leather jerkin.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Thou must be my ambassador to him, Thersites.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Who, I? Why, he'll answer nobody; he professes not answering. Speaking is for beggars: he wears his tongue in's arms. I will put on his presence. Let Patroclus make his demands to me, you shall see the pageant of Ajax.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: To him, Patroclus. Tell him I humbly desire the valiant Ajax to invite the most valorous Hector to come unarm'd to my tent; and to procure safe conduct for his person of the magnanimous and most illustrious six-or-seven-times-honour'd Captain General of the Grecian army, Agamemnon. Do this.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Jove bless great Ajax!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Hum!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: I come from the worthy Achilles-

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Who most humbly desires you to invite Hector to his tent-

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Hum!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: And to procure safe conduct from Agamemnon.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Agamemnon?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Ay, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Ha!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: What you say to't?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: God buy you, with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Your answer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: If tomorrow be a fair day, by eleven of the clock it will go one way or other. Howsoever, he shall pay for me ere he has me.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Your answer, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Fare ye well, with all my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Why, but he is not in this tune, is he?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: No, but out of tune thus. What music will be in him when Hector has knock'd out his brains, I know not; but, I am sure, none; unless the fiddler Apollo get his sinews to make catlings on.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Come, thou shalt bear a letter to him straight.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Let me bear another to his horse; for that's the more capable creature.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: My mind is troubled, like a fountain stirr'd; And I myself see not the bottom of it.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Would the fountain of your mind were clear again, that I might water an ass at it. I had rather be a tick in a sheep than such a valiant ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: See, ho! Who is that there?

dialogues.speaker: Deiphobus
dialogues.line: It is the Lord Aeneas.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Is the Prince there in person? Had I so good occasion to lie long As you, Prince Paris, nothing but heavenly business Should rob my bed-mate of my company.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: That's my mind too. Good morrow, Lord Aeneas.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: A valiant Greek, Aeneas-take his hand: Witness the process of your speech, wherein You told how Diomed, a whole week by days, Did haunt you in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Health to you, valiant sir, During all question of the gentle truce; But when I meet you arm'd, as black defiance As heart can think or courage execute.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: The one and other Diomed embraces. Our bloods are now in calm; and so long health! But when contention and occasion meet, By Jove, I'll play the hunter for thy life With all my force, pursuit, and policy.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: And thou shalt hunt a lion that will fly With his face backward. In humane gentleness, Welcome to Troy! Now, by Anchises' life, Welcome indeed! By Venus' hand I swear No man alive can love in such a sort The thing he means to kill, more excellently.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: We sympathise. Jove let Aeneas live, If to my sword his fate be not the glory, A thousand complete courses of the sun! But in mine emulous honour let him die With every joint a wound, and that tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: We know each other well.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: We do; and long to know each other worse.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: This is the most despiteful gentle greeting, The noblest hateful love, that e'er I heard of. What business, lord, so early?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: I was sent for to the King; but why, I know not.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: His purpose meets you: 'twas to bring this Greek To Calchas' house, and there to render him, For the enfreed Antenor, the fair Cressid. Let's have your company; or, if you please, Haste there before us. I constantly believe- Or rather call my thought a certain knowledge- My brother Troilus lodges there tonight. Rouse him and give him note of our approach, With the whole quality wherefore; I fear We shall be much unwelcome.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: That I assure you: Troilus had rather Troy were borne to Greece Than Cressid borne from Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: There is no help; The bitter disposition of the time Will have it so. On, lord; we'll follow you.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Good morrow, all.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: And tell me, noble Diomed, faith, tell me true, Even in the soul of sound good-fellowship, Who in your thoughts deserves fair Helen best, Myself, or Menelaus?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Both alike: He merits well to have her that doth seek her, Not making any scruple of her soilure, With such a hell of pain and world of charge; And you as well to keep her that defend her, Not palating the taste of her dishonour, With such a costly loss of wealth and friends. He like a puling cuckold would drink up The lees and dregs of a flat tamed piece; You, like a lecher, out of whorish loins Are pleas'd to breed out your inheritors. Both merits pois'd, each weighs nor less nor more, But he as he, the heavier for a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: You are too bitter to your country-woman.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: She's bitter to her country. Hear me, Paris: For every false drop in her bawdy veins A Grecian's life hath sunk; for every scruple Of her contaminated carrion weight A Trojan hath been slain. Since she could speak, She hath not given so many good words breath As for her Greeks and Trojans suff'red death.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Fair Diomed, you do as chapmen do, Dispraise the thing that you desire to buy; But we in silence hold this virtue well, We'll not commend what we intend to sell. Here lies our way.

scenes.location: Troy. The court of Pandarus' house.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Dear, trouble not yourself; the morn is cold.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Then, sweet my lord, I'll call mine uncle down; He shall unbolt the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Trouble him not; To bed, to bed! Sleep kill those pretty eyes, And give as soft attachment to thy senses As infants empty of all thought!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Good morrow, then.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I prithee now, to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Are you aweary of me?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O Cressida! but that the busy day, Wak'd by the lark, hath rous'd the ribald crows, And dreaming night will hide our joys no longer, I would not from thee.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Night hath been too brief.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Beshrew the witch! with venomous wights she stays As tediously as hell, but flies the grasps of love With wings more momentary-swift than thought. You will catch cold, and curse me.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Prithee tarry. You men will never tarry. O foolish Cressid! I might have still held off, And then you would have tarried. Hark! there's one up.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What's all the doors open here?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: It is your uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: A pestilence on him! Now will he be mocking. I shall have such a life!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: How now, how now! How go maidenheads? Here, you maid! Where's my cousin Cressid?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Go hang yourself, you naughty mocking uncle. You bring me to do, and then you flout me too.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: To do what? to do what? Let her say what. What have I brought you to do?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Come, come, beshrew your heart! You'll ne'er be good, nor suffer others.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ha, ha! Alas, poor wretch! Ah, poor capocchia! Hast not slept tonight? Would he not, a naughty man, let it sleep? A bugbear take him!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Did not I tell you? Would he were knock'd i' th' head! Who's that at door? Good uncle, go and see. My lord, come you again into my chamber. You smile and mock me, as if I meant naughtily.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Ha! ha!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Come, you are deceiv'd, I think of no such thing. How earnestly they knock! Pray you come in: I would not for half Troy have you seen here.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Who's there? What's the matter? Will you beat down the door? How now? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Good morrow, lord, good morrow.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Who's there? My lord Aeneas? By my troth, I knew you not. What news with you so early?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Is not Prince Troilus here?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Here! What should he do here?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Come, he is here, my lord; do not deny him. It doth import him much to speak with me.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Is he here, say you? It's more than I know, I'll be sworn. For my own part, I came in late. What should he do here?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Who, nay then! Come, come, you'll do him wrong ere you are ware; you'll be so true to him to be false to him. Do not you know of him, but yet go fetch him hither; go.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: How now! What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: My lord, I scarce have leisure to salute you, My matter is so rash. There is at hand Paris your brother, and Deiphobus, The Grecian Diomed, and our Antenor Deliver'd to us; and for him forthwith, Ere the first sacrifice, within this hour, We must give up to Diomedes' hand The Lady Cressida.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Is it so concluded?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: By Priam and the general state of Troy. They are at hand, and ready to effect it.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: How my achievements mock me! I will go meet them; and, my Lord Aeneas, We met by chance; you did not find me here.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Good, good, my lord, the secrets of neighbour Pandar Have not more gift in taciturnity.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Is't possible? No sooner got but lost? The devil take Antenor! The young prince will go mad. A plague upon Antenor! I would they had broke's neck.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: How now! What's the matter? Who was here?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ah, ah!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Why sigh you so profoundly? Where's my lord? Gone? Tell me, sweet uncle, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Would I were as deep under the earth as I am above!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O the gods! What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Pray thee get thee in. Would thou hadst ne'er been born! I knew thou wouldst be his death! O, poor gentleman! A plague upon Antenor!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Good uncle, I beseech you, on my knees I beseech you, what's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Thou must be gone, wench, thou must be gone; thou art chang'd for Antenor; thou must to thy father, and be gone from Troilus. 'Twill be his death; 'twill be his bane; he cannot bear it.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O you immortal gods! I will not go.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Thou must.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I will not, uncle. I have forgot my father; I know no touch of consanguinity, No kin, no love, no blood, no soul so near me As the sweet Troilus. O you gods divine, Make Cressid's name the very crown of falsehood, If ever she leave Troilus! Time, force, and death, Do to this body what extremes you can, But the strong base and building of my love Is as the very centre of the earth, Drawing all things to it. I'll go in and weep-

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Do, do.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Tear my bright hair, and scratch my praised cheeks, Crack my clear voice with sobs and break my heart, With sounding ‘Troilus.' I will not go from Troy.

scenes.location: Troy. A street before Pandarus' house.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: It is great morning; and the hour prefix'd For her delivery to this valiant Greek Comes fast upon. Good my brother Troilus, Tell you the lady what she is to do And haste her to the purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Walk into her house. I'll bring her to the Grecian presently; And to his hand when I deliver her, Think it an altar, and thy brother Troilus A priest, there off'ring to it his own heart.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: I know what 'tis to love, And would, as I shall pity, I could help! Please you walk in, my lords?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Be moderate, be moderate.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Why tell you me of moderation? The grief is fine, full, perfect, that I taste, And violenteth in a sense as strong As that which causeth it. How can I moderate it? If I could temporize with my affections Or brew it to a weak and colder palate, The like allayment could I give my grief. My love admits no qualifying dross; No more my grief, in such a precious loss.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Here, here, here he comes. Ah, sweet ducks!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O Troilus! Troilus!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: What a pair of spectacles is here! Let me embrace too. ‘O heart,' as the goodly saying is,- O heart, heavy heart, Why sigh'st thou without breaking? where he answers again Because thou canst not ease thy smart By friendship nor by speaking. There was never a truer rhyme. Let us cast away nothing, for we may live to have need of such a verse. We see it, we see it. How now, lambs!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Cressid, I love thee in so strain'd a purity That the bless'd gods, as angry with my fancy, More bright in zeal than the devotion which Cold lips blow to their deities, take thee from me.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Have the gods envy?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, ay, ay; 'tis too plain a case.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: And is it true that I must go from Troy?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: A hateful truth.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: What! and from Troilus too?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: From Troy and Troilus.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Is't possible?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: And suddenly; where injury of chance Puts back leave-taking, justles roughly by All time of pause, rudely beguiles our lips Of all rejoindure, forcibly prevents Our lock'd embrasures, strangles our dear vows Even in the birth of our own labouring breath. We two, that with so many thousand sighs Did buy each other, must poorly sell ourselves With the rude brevity and discharge of one. Injurious time now with a robber's haste Crams his rich thiev'ry up, he knows not how. As many farewells as be stars in heaven, With distinct breath and consign'd kisses to them, He fumbles up into a loose adieu, And scants us with a single famish'd kiss, Distasted with the salt of broken tears.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: My lord, is the lady ready?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hark! you are call'd. Some say the Genius Cries so to him that instantly must die. Bid them have patience; she shall come anon.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Where are my tears? Rain, to lay this wind, or my heart will be blown up by my throat!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I must then to the Grecians?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: No remedy.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: A woeful Cressid 'mongst the merry Greeks! When shall we see again?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hear me, my love. Be thou but true of heart.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I true? How now! What wicked deem is this?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Nay, we must use expostulation kindly, For it is parting from us. I speak not ‘Be thou true' as fearing thee, For I will throw my glove to Death himself That there's no maculation in thy heart; But ‘Be thou true' say I to fashion in My sequent protestation: be thou true, And I will see thee.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O! you shall be expos'd, my lord, to dangers As infinite as imminent! But I'll be true.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: And I'll grow friend with danger. Wear this sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: And you this glove. When shall I see you?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I will corrupt the Grecian sentinels To give thee nightly visitation. But yet be true.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O heavens! ‘Be true' again!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hear why I speak it, love. The Grecian youths are full of quality; They're loving, well compos'd, with gifts of nature, Flowing and swelling o'er with arts and exercise. How novelty may move, and parts with person, Alas, a kind of godly jealousy, Which, I beseech you, call a virtuous sin, Makes me afear'd.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O heavens! you love me not!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Die I a villain then! In this I do not call your faith in question So mainly as my merit. I cannot sing, Nor heel the high lavolt, nor sweeten talk, Nor play at subtle games; fair virtues all, To which the Grecians are most prompt and pregnant; But I can tell that in each grace of these There lurks a still and dumb-discoursive devil That tempts most cunningly. But be not tempted.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Do you think I will?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: No. But something may be done that we will not; And sometimes we are devils to ourselves, When we will tempt the frailty of our powers, Presuming on their changeful potency.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Nay, good my lord!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Come, kiss; and let us part.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Brother Troilus!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Good brother, come you hither; And bring Aeneas and the Grecian with you.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: My lord, will you be true?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Who, I? Alas, it is my vice, my fault! Whiles others fish with craft for great opinion, I with great truth catch mere simplicity; Whilst some with cunning gild their copper crowns, With truth and plainness I do wear mine bare. Fear not my truth: the moral of my wit Is plain and true; there's all the reach of it. Welcome, Sir Diomed! Here is the lady Which for Antenor we deliver you; At the port, lord, I'll give her to thy hand, And by the way possess thee what she is. Entreat her fair; and, by my soul, fair Greek, If e'er thou stand at mercy of my sword, Name Cressid, and thy life shall be as safe As Priam is in Ilion.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Fair Lady Cressid, So please you, save the thanks this prince expects. The lustre in your eye, heaven in your cheek, Pleads your fair usage; and to Diomed You shall be mistress, and command him wholly.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Grecian, thou dost not use me courteously To shame the zeal of my petition to thee In praising her. I tell thee, lord of Greece, She is as far high-soaring o'er thy praises As thou unworthy to be call'd her servant. I charge thee use her well, even for my charge; For, by the dreadful Pluto, if thou dost not, Though the great bulk Achilles be thy guard, I'll cut thy throat.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: O, be not mov'd, Prince Troilus. Let me be privileg'd by my place and message To be a speaker free: when I am hence I'll answer to my lust. And know you, lord, I'll nothing do on charge: to her own worth She shall be priz'd. But that you say ‘Be't so,' I speak it in my spirit and honour, ‘No.'

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Come, to the port. I'll tell thee, Diomed, This brave shall oft make thee to hide thy head. Lady, give me your hand; and, as we walk, To our own selves bend we our needful talk.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: Hark! Hector's trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: How have we spent this morning! The Prince must think me tardy and remiss, That swore to ride before him to the field.

dialogues.speaker: Paris
dialogues.line: 'Tis Troilus' fault. Come, come to field with him.

dialogues.speaker: Deiphobus
dialogues.line: Let us make ready straight.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Yea, with a bridegroom's fresh alacrity Let us address to tend on Hector's heels. The glory of our Troy doth this day lie On his fair worth and single chivalry.

scenes.location: The Grecian camp. Lists set out.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Here art thou in appointment fresh and fair, Anticipating time with starting courage. Give with thy trumpet a loud note to Troy, Thou dreadful Ajax, that the appalled air May pierce the head of the great combatant, And hale him hither.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Thou, trumpet, there's my purse. Now crack thy lungs and split thy brazen pipe; Blow, villain, till thy sphered bias cheek Out-swell the colic of puff'd Aquilon. Come, stretch thy chest, and let thy eyes spout blood: Thou blowest for Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: No trumpet answers.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: 'Tis but early days.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Is not yond Diomed, with Calchas' daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: 'Tis he, I ken the manner of his gait: He rises on the toe. That spirit of his In aspiration lifts him from the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Is this the Lady Cressid?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Even she.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Most dearly welcome to the Greeks, sweet lady.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Our general doth salute you with a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Yet is the kindness but particular; 'Twere better she were kiss'd in general.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: And very courtly counsel: I'll begin. So much for Nestor.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I'll take that winter from your lips, fair lady. Achilles bids you welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: I had good argument for kissing once.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: But that's no argument for kissing now; For thus popp'd Paris in his hardiment, And parted thus you and your argument.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: O deadly gall, and theme of all our scorns! For which we lose our heads to gild his horns.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: The first was Menelaus' kiss; this, mine: Patroclus kisses you.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: O, this is trim!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Paris and I kiss evermore for him.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: I'll have my kiss, sir. Lady, by your leave.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: In kissing, do you render or receive?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Both take and give.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I'll make my match to live, The kiss you take is better than you give; Therefore no kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: I'll give you boot; I'll give you three for one.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: You are an odd man; give even or give none.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: An odd man, lady! Every man is odd.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: No, Paris is not; for you know 'tis true That you are odd, and he is even with you.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: You fillip me o' th'head.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: No, I'll be sworn.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: It were no match, your nail against his horn. May I, sweet lady, beg a kiss of you?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: You may.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: I do desire it.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Why, beg then.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Why then, for Venus' sake give me a kiss When Helen is a maid again, and his.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I am your debtor; claim it when 'tis due.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Never's my day, and then a kiss of you.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Lady, a word. I'll bring you to your father.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: A woman of quick sense.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Fie, fie upon her! There's language in her eye, her cheek, her lip, Nay, her foot speaks; her wanton spirits look out At every joint and motive of her body. O! these encounterers so glib of tongue That give a coasting welcome ere it comes, And wide unclasp the tables of their thoughts To every tickling reader! Set them down For sluttish spoils of opportunity, And daughters of the game.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: The Trojans' trumpet.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Yonder comes the troop. Enter Hector, armed; Aeneas, Troilus, Paris, Deiphobus and other Trojans, with attendants.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Hail, all you state of Greece! What shall be done To him that victory commands? Or do you purpose A victor shall be known? Will you the knights Shall to the edge of all extremity Pursue each other, or shall be divided By any voice or order of the field? Hector bade ask.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Which way would Hector have it?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: He cares not; he'll obey conditions.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: 'Tis done like Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: But securely done, A little proudly, and great deal misprising The knight oppos'd.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: If not Achilles, sir, What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: If not Achilles, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Therefore Achilles. But whate'er, know this: In the extremity of great and little Valour and pride excel themselves in Hector; The one almost as infinite as all, The other blank as nothing. Weigh him well, And that which looks like pride is courtesy. This Ajax is half made of Hector's blood; In love whereof half Hector stays at home; Half heart, half hand, half Hector comes to seek This blended knight, half Trojan and half Greek.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: A maiden battle then? O! I perceive you.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Here is Sir Diomed. Go, gentle knight, Stand by our Ajax. As you and Lord Aeneas Consent upon the order of their fight, So be it; either to the uttermost, Or else a breath. The combatants being kin Half stints their strife before their strokes begin. Ajax and Hector enter the lists.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: They are oppos'd already.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: What Trojan is that same that looks so heavy?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: The youngest son of Priam, a true knight; Not yet mature, yet matchless; firm of word; Speaking in deeds and deedless in his tongue; Not soon provok'd, nor being provok'd soon calm'd; His heart and hand both open and both free; For what he has he gives, what thinks he shows, Yet gives he not till judgement guide his bounty, Nor dignifies an impure thought with breath; Manly as Hector, but more dangerous; For Hector in his blaze of wrath subscribes To tender objects, but he in heat of action Is more vindicative than jealous love. They call him Troilus, and on him erect A second hope as fairly built as Hector. Thus says Aeneas, one that knows the youth Even to his inches, and, with private soul, Did in great Ilion thus translate him to me.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: They are in action.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Now, Ajax, hold thine own!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hector, thou sleep'st; awake thee!

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: His blows are well dispos'd. There, Ajax!

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: You must no more.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Princes, enough, so please you.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I am not warm yet; let us fight again.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: As Hector pleases.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Why, then will I no more. Thou art, great lord, my father's sister's son, A cousin-german to great Priam's seed; The obligation of our blood forbids A gory emulation 'twixt us twain: Were thy commixtion Greek and Trojan so That thou could'st say ‘This hand is Grecian all, And this is Trojan; the sinews of this leg All Greek, and this all Troy; my mother's blood Runs on the dexter cheek, and this sinister Bounds in my father's; by Jove multipotent, Thou shouldst not bear from me a Greekish member Wherein my sword had not impressure made Of our rank feud; but the just gods gainsay That any drop thou borrow'dst from thy mother, My sacred aunt, should by my mortal sword Be drained! Let me embrace thee, Ajax. By him that thunders, thou hast lusty arms; Hector would have them fall upon him thus. Cousin, all honour to thee!

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I thank thee, Hector. Thou art too gentle and too free a man. I came to kill thee, cousin, and bear hence A great addition earned in thy death.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Not Neoptolemus so mirable, On whose bright crest Fame with her loud'st Oyes Cries ‘This is he!' could promise to himself A thought of added honour torn from Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: There is expectance here from both the sides What further you will do.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: We'll answer it: The issue is embracement. Ajax, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: If I might in entreaties find success, As seld' I have the chance, I would desire My famous cousin to our Grecian tents.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: 'Tis Agamemnon's wish; and great Achilles Doth long to see unarm'd the valiant Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Aeneas, call my brother Troilus to me, And signify this loving interview To the expecters of our Trojan part; Desire them home. Give me thy hand, my cousin; I will go eat with thee, and see your knights. Agamemnon and the rest of the Greeks come forward.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Great Agamemnon comes to meet us here.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: The worthiest of them tell me name by name; But for Achilles, my own searching eyes Shall find him by his large and portly size.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Worthy all arms! as welcome as to one That would be rid of such an enemy. But that's no welcome. Understand more clear, What's past and what's to come is strew'd with husks And formless ruin of oblivion; But in this extant moment, faith and troth, Strain'd purely from all hollow bias-drawing, Bids thee with most divine integrity, From heart of very heart, great Hector, welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I thank thee, most imperious Agamemnon.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: My well-fam'd lord of Troy, no less to you.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: Let me confirm my princely brother's greeting. You brace of warlike brothers, welcome hither.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Who must we answer?

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: The noble Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: O you, my lord? By Mars his gauntlet, thanks! Mock not that I affect the untraded oath; Your quondam wife swears still by Venus' glove. She's well, but bade me not commend her to you.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: Name her not now, sir; she's a deadly theme.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: O, pardon; I offend.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: I have, thou gallant Trojan, seen thee oft, Labouring for destiny, make cruel way Through ranks of Greekish youth; and I have seen thee, As hot as Perseus, spur thy Phrygian steed, Despising many forfeits and subduements, When thou hast hung thy advanced sword i' th'air, Not letting it decline on the declined; That I have said to some my standers-by ‘Lo, Jupiter is yonder, dealing life!' And I have seen thee pause and take thy breath, When that a ring of Greeks have shrap'd thee in, Like an Olympian wrestling. This have I seen; But this thy countenance, still lock'd in steel, I never saw till now. I knew thy grandsire, And once fought with him. He was a soldier good, But, by great Mars, the captain of us all, Never like thee. O, let an old man embrace thee; And, worthy warrior, welcome to our tents.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: 'Tis the old Nestor.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Let me embrace thee, good old chronicle, That hast so long walk'd hand in hand with time. Most reverend Nestor, I am glad to clasp thee.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: I would my arms could match thee in contention As they contend with thee in courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I would they could.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Ha! By this white beard, I'd fight with thee tomorrow. Well, welcome, welcome! I have seen the time.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: I wonder now how yonder city stands, When we have here her base and pillar by us.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I know your favour, Lord Ulysses, well. Ah, sir, there's many a Greek and Trojan dead, Since first I saw yourself and Diomed In Ilion on your Greekish embassy.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Sir, I foretold you then what would ensue. My prophecy is but half his journey yet; For yonder walls, that pertly front your town, Yon towers, whose wanton tops do buss the clouds, Must kiss their own feet.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I must not believe you. There they stand yet; and modestly I think The fall of every Phrygian stone will cost A drop of Grecian blood. The end crowns all; And that old common arbitrator, Time, Will one day end it.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: So to him we leave it. Most gentle and most valiant Hector, welcome. After the General, I beseech you next To feast with me and see me at my tent.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I shall forestall thee, Lord Ulysses, thou! Now, Hector, I have fed mine eyes on thee; I have with exact view perus'd thee, Hector, And quoted joint by joint.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Is this Achilles?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I am Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Stand fair, I pray thee; let me look on thee.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Behold thy fill.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Nay, I have done already.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Thou art too brief. I will the second time, As I would buy thee, view thee limb by limb.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: O, like a book of sport thou'lt read me o'er; But there's more in me than thou understand'st. Why dost thou so oppress me with thine eye?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Tell me, you heavens, in which part of his body Shall I destroy him? Whether there, or there, or there? That I may give the local wound a name, And make distinct the very breach whereout Hector's great spirit flew. Answer me, heavens.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: It would discredit the blest gods, proud man, To answer such a question. Stand again. Think'st thou to catch my life so pleasantly As to prenominate in nice conjecture Where thou wilt hit me dead?

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I tell thee yea.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Wert thou an oracle to tell me so, I'd not believe thee. Henceforth guard thee well; For I'll not kill thee there, nor there, nor there; But, by the forge that stithied Mars his helm, I'll kill thee everywhere, yea, o'er and o'er. You wisest Grecians, pardon me this brag. His insolence draws folly from my lips; But I'll endeavour deeds to match these words, Or may I never-

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Do not chafe thee, cousin; And you, Achilles, let these threats alone Till accident or purpose bring you to't. You may have every day enough of Hector, If you have stomach. The general state, I fear, Can scarce entreat you to be odd with him.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I pray you let us see you in the field; We have had pelting wars since you refus'd The Grecians' cause.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Dost thou entreat me, Hector? Tomorrow do I meet thee, fell as death; Tonight all friends.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Thy hand upon that match.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: First, all you peers of Greece, go to my tent; There in the full convive we; afterwards, As Hector's leisure and your bounties shall Concur together, severally entreat him. Beat loud the tambourines, let the trumpets blow, That this great soldier may his welcome know.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: My Lord Ulysses, tell me, I beseech you, In what place of the field doth Calchas keep?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: At Menelaus' tent, most princely Troilus. There Diomed doth feast with him tonight, Who neither looks upon the heaven nor earth, But gives all gaze and bent of amorous view On the fair Cressid.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Shall I, sweet lord, be bound to you so much, After we part from Agamemnon's tent, To bring me thither?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: You shall command me, sir. As gentle tell me of what honour was This Cressida in Troy? Had she no lover there That wails her absence?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O, sir, to such as boasting show their scars A mock is due. Will you walk on, my lord? She was belov'd, she lov'd; she is, and doth; But still sweet love is food for fortune's tooth.

scenes.location: The Grecian camp. Before the tent of Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I'll heat his blood with Greekish wine tonight, Which with my scimitar I'll cool tomorrow. Patroclus, let us feast him to the height.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Here comes Thersites.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: How now, thou core of envy! Thou crusty batch of nature, what's the news?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Why, thou picture of what thou seemest, and idol of idiot worshippers, here's a letter for thee.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: From whence, fragment?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Why, thou full dish of fool, from Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Who keeps the tent now?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: The surgeon's box or the patient's wound.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Well said, adversity! And what needs these tricks?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Prithee, be silent, boy; I profit not by thy talk; thou art said to be Achilles' male varlet.

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Male varlet, you rogue! What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Why, his masculine whore. Now, the rotten diseases of the south, the guts-griping ruptures, catarrhs, loads o' gravel in the back, lethargies, cold palsies, raw eyes, dirt-rotten livers, wheezing lungs, bladders full of imposthume, sciaticas, lime-kilns i' th' palm, incurable bone-ache, and the rivelled fee-simple of the tetter, take and take again such preposterous discoveries!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Why, thou damnable box of envy, thou, what meanest thou to curse thus?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Do I curse thee?

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Why, no, you ruinous butt; you whoreson indistinguishable cur, no.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: No! Why art thou, then, exasperate, thou idle immaterial skein of sleave silk, thou green sarcenet flap for a sore eye, thou tassel of a prodigal's purse, thou? Ah, how the poor world is  pestered with such water-flies, diminutives of nature!

dialogues.speaker: Patroclus
dialogues.line: Out, gall!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Finch egg!

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: My sweet Patroclus, I am thwarted quite From my great purpose in tomorrow's battle. Here is a letter from Queen Hecuba, A token from her daughter, my fair love, Both taxing me and gaging me to keep An oath that I have sworn. I will not break it. Fall Greeks; fail fame; honour or go or stay; My major vow lies here, this I'll obey. Come, come, Thersites, help to trim my tent; This night in banqueting must all be spent. Away, Patroclus!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: With too much blood and too little brain these two may run mad; but, if with too much brain and too little blood they do, I'll be a curer of madmen. Here's Agamemnon, an honest fellow enough, and one that loves quails, but he has not so much brain as ear-wax; and the goodly transformation of Jupiter there, his brother, the bull, the primitive statue and oblique memorial of cuckolds, a thrifty shoeing-horn in a chain at his brother's leg, to what form but that he is, should wit larded with malice, and malice forced with wit, turn him to? To an ass, were nothing: he is both ass and ox. To an ox, were nothing: he is both ox and ass. To be a dog, a mule, a cat, a fitchook, a toad, a lizard, an owl, a puttock, or a herring without a roe, I would not care; but to be Menelaus, I would conspire against destiny. Ask me not what I would be, if I were not Thersites; for I care not to be the louse of a lazar, so I were not Menelaus. Hey-day! sprites and fires! Diomedes with lights.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: We go wrong, we go wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: No, yonder 'tis; There, where we see the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I trouble you.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: No, not a whit.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Here comes himself to guide you.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Welcome, brave Hector; welcome, Princes all.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: So now, fair Prince of Troy, I bid good night; Ajax commands the guard to tend on you.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Thanks, and good night to the Greeks' general.

dialogues.speaker: Menelaus
dialogues.line: Good night, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Good night, sweet Lord Menelaus.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Sweet draught! ‘Sweet' quoth a'! Sweet sink, sweet sewer!

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Good night and welcome, both at once, to those That go or tarry.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Old Nestor tarries; and you too, Diomed, Keep Hector company an hour or two.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: I cannot, lord; I have important business, The tide whereof is now. Good night, great Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Give me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Follow his torch; he goes to Calchas' tent; I'll keep you company.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Sweet sir, you honour me.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: And so, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Come, come, enter my tent.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: That same Diomed's a false-hearted rogue, a most unjust knave; I will no more trust him when he leers than I will a serpent when he hisses. He will spend his mouth and promise, like Brabbler the hound; but when he performs, astronomers foretell it: it is prodigious, there will come some change; the sun borrows of the moon when Diomed keeps his word. I will rather leave to see Hector than not to dog him. They say he keeps a Trojan drab, and uses the traitor Calchas' tent. I'll after. Nothing but lechery! All incontinent varlets!

scenes.location: The Grecian camp. Before Calchas' tent.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: What, are you up here, ho! Speak.

dialogues.speaker: Calchas
dialogues.line: Who calls?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Diomed. Calchas, I think. Where's your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Calchas
dialogues.line: She comes to you. Enter Troilus and Ulysses, at a distance; after them Thersites.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Stand where the torch may not discover us.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Cressid comes forth to him.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: How now, my charge!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Now, my sweet guardian! Hark, a word with you.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Yea, so familiar?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: She will sing any man at first sight.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: And any man may sing her, if he can take her cliff; she's noted.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Will you remember?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Remember! Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Nay, but do, then; And let your mind be coupled with your words.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: What should she remember?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: List!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Sweet honey Greek, tempt me no more to folly.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Roguery!

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Nay, then-

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I'll tell you what-

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Fo, fo! come, tell a pin; you are a forsworn.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: In faith, I cannot. What would you have me do?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: A juggling trick, to be secretly open.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: What did you swear you would bestow on me?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I prithee, do not hold me to mine oath; Bid me do anything but that, sweet Greek.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hold, patience!

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: How now, Trojan!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Diomed!

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: No, no, good night; I'll be your fool no more.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Thy better must.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Hark! a word in your ear.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O plague and madness!

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: You are moved, Prince; let us depart, I pray, Lest your displeasure should enlarge itself To wrathful terms. This place is dangerous; The time right deadly; I beseech you, go.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Behold, I pray you.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Nay, good my lord, go off; You flow to great distraction; come, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I pray thee stay.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: You have not patience; come.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I pray you, stay; by hell and all hell's torments, I will not speak a word.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: And so, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Nay, but you part in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Doth that grieve thee? O withered truth!

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: How now, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: By Jove, I will be patient.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Guardian! Why, Greek!

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Fo, fo! adieu! you palter.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: In faith, I do not. Come hither once again.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: You shake, my lord, at something; will you go? You will break out.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: She strokes his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Come, come.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Nay, stay; by Jove, I will not speak a word: There is between my will and all offences A guard of patience. Stay a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: How the devil Luxury, with his fat rump and potato finger, tickles these together! Fry, lechery, fry!

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: But will you, then?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: In faith, I will, la; never trust me else.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Give me some token for the surety of it.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: I'll fetch you one.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: You have sworn patience.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
