dialogues.line: Fear me not, my lord; I will not be myself, nor have cognition Of what I feel. I am all patience.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Now the pledge; now, now, now!

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Here, Diomed, keep this sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O beauty! where is thy faith?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: My lord!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I will be patient; outwardly I will.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: You look upon that sleeve; behold it well. He lov'd me-O false wench!-Give't me again.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Whose was't?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: It is no matter, now I have't again. I will not meet with you tomorrow night. I prithee, Diomed, visit me no more.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Now she sharpens. Well said, whetstone.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: I shall have it.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: What, this?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Ay, that.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: O all you gods! O pretty, pretty pledge! Thy master now lies thinking on his bed Of thee and me, and sighs, and takes my glove, And gives memorial dainty kisses to it, As I kiss thee. Nay, do not snatch it from me; He that takes that doth take my heart withal.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: I had your heart before; this follows it.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: I did swear patience.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: You shall not have it, Diomed; faith, you shall not; I'll give you something else.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: I will have this. Whose was it?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: It is no matter.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Come, tell me whose it was.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: 'Twas one's that lov'd me better than you will. But, now you have it, take it.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Whose was it?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: By all Diana's waiting women yond, And by herself, I will not tell you whose.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Tomorrow will I wear it on my helm, And grieve his spirit that dares not challenge it.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Wert thou the devil and wor'st it on thy horn, It should be challeng'd.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Well, well, 'tis done, 'tis past; and yet it is not; I will not keep my word.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Why, then farewell; Thou never shalt mock Diomed again.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: You shall not go. One cannot speak a word But it straight starts you.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: I do not like this fooling.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Nor I, by Pluto; but that that likes not you Pleases me best.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: What, shall I come? The hour?

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Ay, come; O Jove! Do come. I shall be plagu'd.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Farewell till then.

dialogues.speaker: Cressida
dialogues.line: Good night. I prithee come. Troilus, farewell! One eye yet looks on thee; But with my heart the other eye doth see. Ah, poor our sex! this fault in us I find, The error of our eye directs our mind. What error leads must err; O, then conclude, Minds sway'd by eyes are full of turpitude.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: A proof of strength she could not publish more, Unless she said ‘My mind is now turn'd whore.'

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: All's done, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: It is.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Why stay we, then?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: To make a recordation to my soul Of every syllable that here was spoke. But if I tell how these two did co-act, Shall I not lie in publishing a truth? Sith yet there is a credence in my heart, An esperance so obstinately strong, That doth invert th'attest of eyes and ears; As if those organs had deceptious functions Created only to calumniate. Was Cressid here?

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: I cannot conjure, Trojan.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: She was not, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Most sure she was.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Why, my negation hath no taste of madness.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: Nor mine, my lord. Cressid was here but now.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Let it not be believ'd for womanhood. Think, we had mothers; do not give advantage To stubborn critics, apt, without a theme, For depravation, to square the general sex By Cressid's rule. Rather think this not Cressid.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: What hath she done, Prince, that can soil our mothers?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Nothing at all, unless that this were she.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Will he swagger himself out on's own eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: This she? No; this is Diomed's Cressida. If beauty have a soul, this is not she; If souls guide vows, if vows be sanctimonies, If sanctimony be the god's delight, If there be rule in unity itself, This was not she. O madness of discourse, That cause sets up with and against itself! Bi-fold authority! where reason can revolt Without perdition, and loss assume all reason Without revolt: this is, and is not, Cressid. Of this strange nature, that a thing inseparate Divides more wider than the sky and earth; And yet the spacious breadth of this division Admits no orifice for a point as subtle As Ariachne's broken woof to enter. Instance, O instance! strong as Pluto's gates: Cressid is mine, tied with the bonds of heaven. Instance, O instance! strong as heaven itself: The bonds of heaven are slipp'd, dissolv'd, and loos'd; And with another knot, five-finger-tied, The fractions of her faith, orts of her love, The fragments, scraps, the bits, and greasy relics Of her o'er-eaten faith, are given to Diomed.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: May worthy Troilus be half attach'd With that which here his passion doth express?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Ay, Greek; and that shall be divulged well In characters as red as Mars his heart Inflam'd with Venus. Never did young man fancy With so eternal and so fix'd a soul. Hark, Greek: as much as I do Cressid love, So much by weight hate I her Diomed. That sleeve is mine that he'll bear on his helm; Were it a casque compos'd by Vulcan's skill My sword should bite it. Not the dreadful spout Which shipmen do the hurricano call, Constring'd in mass by the almighty sun, Shall dizzy with more clamour Neptune's ear In his descent than shall my prompted sword Falling on Diomed.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: He'll tickle it for his concupy.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O Cressid! O false Cressid! false, false, false! Let all untruths stand by thy stained name, And they'll seem glorious.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: O, contain yourself; Your passion draws ears hither.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: I have been seeking you this hour, my lord. Hector, by this, is arming him in Troy; Ajax, your guard, stays to conduct you home.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Have with you, Prince. My courteous lord, adieu. Fairwell, revolted fair! and, Diomed, Stand fast, and wear a castle on thy head.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: I'll bring you to the gates.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Accept distracted thanks. THERSITES. Would I could meet that rogue Diomed! I would croak like a raven; I would bode, I would bode. Patroclus will give me anything for the intelligence of this whore; the parrot will not do more for an almond than he for a commodious drab. Lechery, lechery! Still wars and lechery! Nothing else holds fashion. A burning devil take them!

dialogues.speaker: Andromache
dialogues.line: When was my lord so much ungently temper'd To stop his ears against admonishment? Unarm, unarm, and do not fight today.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: You train me to offend you; get you in. By all the everlasting gods, I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Andromache
dialogues.line: My dreams will, sure, prove ominous to the day.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: No more, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: Where is my brother Hector?

dialogues.speaker: Andromache
dialogues.line: Here, sister, arm'd, and bloody in intent. Consort with me in loud and dear petition, Pursue we him on knees; for I have dreamt Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: O, 'tis true!

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Ho! bid my trumpet sound.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother!

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Be gone, I say. The gods have heard me swear.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows; They are polluted off'rings, more abhorr'd Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: Andromache
dialogues.line: O, be persuaded! Do not count it holy To hurt by being just. It is as lawful, For we would give much, to use violent thefts And rob in the behalf of charity.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow; But vows to every purpose must not hold. Unarm, sweet Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Hold you still, I say. Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate. Life every man holds dear; but the dear man Holds honour far more precious dear than life. How now, young man! Mean'st thou to fight today?

dialogues.speaker: Andromache
dialogues.line: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: No, faith, young Troilus; doff thy harness, youth; I am today i' th'vein of chivalry. Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong, And tempt not yet the brushes of the war. Unarm thee, go; and doubt thou not, brave boy, I'll stand today for thee and me and Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you, Which better fits a lion than a man.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: What vice is that? Good Troilus, chide me for it.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: When many times the captive Grecian falls, Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword, You bid them rise and live.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: O, 'tis fair play!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Fool's play, by heaven, Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: How now? how now?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: For th' love of all the gods, Let's leave the hermit Pity with our mother; And when we have our armours buckled on, The venom'd vengeance ride upon our swords, Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth!

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Fie, savage, fie!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hector, then 'tis wars.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Troilus, I would not have you fight today.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Who should withhold me? Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars Beckoning with fiery truncheon my retire; Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees, Their eyes o'er-galled with recourse of tears; Nor you, my brother, with your true sword drawn, Oppos'd to hinder me, should stop my way, But by my ruin.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: Lay hold upon him, Priam, hold him fast; He is thy crutch; now if thou lose thy stay, Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee, Fall all together.

dialogues.speaker: Priam
dialogues.line: Come, Hector, come, go back. Thy wife hath dreamt; thy mother hath had visions; Cassandra doth foresee; and I myself Am like a prophet suddenly enrapt To tell thee that this day is ominous. Therefore, come back.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Aeneas is a-field; And I do stand engag'd to many Greeks, Even in the faith of valour, to appear This morning to them.

dialogues.speaker: Priam
dialogues.line: Ay, but thou shalt not go.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I must not break my faith. You know me dutiful; therefore, dear sir, Let me not shame respect; but give me leave To take that course by your consent and voice Which you do here forbid me, royal Priam.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: O Priam, yield not to him!

dialogues.speaker: Andromache
dialogues.line: Do not, dear father.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Andromache, I am offended with you. Upon the love you bear me, get you in.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl Makes all these bodements.

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: O, farewell, dear Hector! Look how thou diest. Look how thy eye turns pale. Look how thy wounds do bleed at many vents. Hark how Troy roars; how Hecuba cries out; How poor Andromache shrills her dolours forth; Behold distraction, frenzy, and amazement, Like witless antics, one another meet, And all cry, ‘Hector! Hector's dead! O Hector!'

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Away, away!

dialogues.speaker: Cassandra
dialogues.line: Farewell! yet, soft! Hector, I take my leave. Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: You are amaz'd, my liege, at her exclaim. Go in, and cheer the town; we'll forth, and fight, Do deeds worth praise and tell you them at night.

dialogues.speaker: Priam
dialogues.line: Farewell. The gods with safety stand about thee!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe, I come to lose my arm or win my sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Do you hear, my lord? Do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: Here's a letter come from yond poor girl.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Let me read.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick, so troubles me, and the foolish fortune of this girl, and what one thing, what another, that I shall leave you one o' these days; and I have a rheum in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones that unless a man were curs'd I cannot tell what to think on't. What says she there?

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart; Th'effect doth operate another way. Go, wind, to wind, there turn and change together. My love with words and errors still she feeds, But edifies another with her deeds.

scenes.location: The plain between Troy and the Grecian camp.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go look on. That dissembling abominable varlet, Diomed, has got that same scurvy doting foolish young knave's sleeve of Troy there in his helm. I would fain see them meet, that that same young Trojan ass that loves the whore there might send that Greekish whoremasterly villain with the sleeve back to the dissembling luxurious drab of a sleeve-less errand. O' the other side, the policy of those crafty swearing rascals that stale old mouse-eaten dry cheese, Nestor, and that same dog-fox, Ulysses, is not prov'd worth a blackberry. They set me up, in policy, that mongrel cur, Ajax, against that dog of as bad a kind, Achilles; and now is the cur, Ajax prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm today; whereupon the Grecians begin to proclaim barbarism, and policy grows into an ill opinion. Soft! here comes sleeve, and t'other.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Fly not; for shouldst thou take the river Styx, I would swim after.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Thou dost miscall retire. I do not fly; but advantageous care Withdrew me from the odds of multitude. Have at thee!

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: Hold thy whore, Grecian; now for thy whore, Trojan! now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: What art thou, Greek? Art thou for Hector's match? Art thou of blood and honour?

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: No, no I am a rascal; a scurvy railing knave; a very filthy rogue.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I do believe thee. Live.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a plague break thy neck for frighting me! What's become of the wenching rogues? I think they have swallowed one another. I would laugh at that miracle. Yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself. I'll seek them.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Go, go, my servant, take thou Troilus' horse; Present the fair steed to my lady Cressid. Fellow, commend my service to her beauty; Tell her I have chastis'd the amorous Trojan, And am her knight by proof.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: I go, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Renew, renew! The fierce Polydamas Hath beat down Menon; bastard Margarelon Hath Doreus prisoner, And stands colossus-wise, waving his beam, Upon the pashed corses of the kings Epistrophus and Cedius. Polixenes is slain; Amphimacus and Thoas deadly hurt; Patroclus ta'en, or slain; and Palamedes Sore hurt and bruis'd. The dreadful Sagittary Appals our numbers. Haste we, Diomed, To reinforcement, or we perish all.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Go, bear Patroclus' body to Achilles, And bid the snail-pac'd Ajax arm for shame. There is a thousand Hectors in the field; Now here he fights on Galathe his horse, And there lacks work; anon he's there afoot, And there they fly or die, like scaled sculls Before the belching whale; then is he yonder, And there the strawy Greeks, ripe for his edge, Fall down before him like the mower's swath. Here, there, and everywhere, he leaves and takes; Dexterity so obeying appetite That what he will he does, and does so much That proof is call'd impossibility.

dialogues.speaker: Ulysses
dialogues.line: O, courage, courage, courage, Princes! Great Achilles Is arming, weeping, cursing, vowing vengeance. Patroclus' wounds have rous'd his drowsy blood, Together with his mangled Myrmidons, That noseless, handless, hack'd and chipp'd, come to him, Crying on Hector. Ajax hath lost a friend And foams at mouth, and he is arm'd and at it, Roaring for Troilus; who hath done today Mad and fantastic execution, Engaging and redeeming of himself With such a careless force and forceless care As if that lust, in very spite of cunning, Bade him win all.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Troilus! thou coward Troilus!

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Ay, there, there.

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: So, so, we draw together.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Where is this Hector? Come, come, thou boy-queller, show thy face; Know what it is to meet Achilles angry. Hector! where's Hector? I will none but Hector.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Troilus, thou coward Troilus, show thy head.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Troilus, I say! Where's Troilus?

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: What wouldst thou?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: I would correct him.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: Were I the general, thou shouldst have my office Ere that correction. Troilus, I say! What, Troilus!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: O traitor Diomed! Turn thy false face, thou traitor, And pay thy life thou owest me for my horse.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Ha! art thou there?

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: I'll fight with him alone. Stand, Diomed.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: He is my prize. I will not look upon.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Come, both, you cogging Greeks; have at you both!

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Yea, Troilus? O, well fought, my youngest brother!

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Now do I see thee. Ha! have at thee, Hector!

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Pause, if thou wilt.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: I do disdain thy courtesy, proud Trojan. Be happy that my arms are out of use; My rest and negligence befriend thee now, But thou anon shalt hear of me again; Till when, go seek thy fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Fare thee well. I would have been much more a fresher man, Had I expected thee. How now, my brother!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Ajax hath ta'en Aeneas. Shall it be? No, by the flame of yonder glorious heaven, He shall not carry him; I'll be ta'en too, Or bring him off. Fate, hear me what I say: I reck not though thou end my life today.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Stand, stand, thou Greek; thou art a goodly mark. No? wilt thou not? I like thy armour well; I'll frush it and unlock the rivets all But I'll be master of it. Wilt thou not, beast, abide? Why then, fly on; I'll hunt thee for thy hide.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Come here about me, you my Myrmidons; Mark what I say. Attend me where I wheel; Strike not a stroke, but keep yourselves in breath; And when I have the bloody Hector found, Empale him with your weapons round about; In fellest manner execute your arms. Follow me, sirs, and my proceedings eye. It is decreed Hector the great must die. Enter Menelaus and Paris, fighting; then Thersites.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: The cuckold and the cuckold-maker are at it. Now, bull! Now, dog! 'Loo, Paris, 'loo! now my double-hen'd Spartan! 'loo, Paris, 'loo! The bull has the game. 'Ware horns, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Margarelon
dialogues.line: Turn, slave, and fight.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: What art thou?

dialogues.speaker: Margarelon
dialogues.line: A bastard son of Priam's.

dialogues.speaker: Thersites
dialogues.line: I am a bastard too; I love bastards. I am a bastard begot, bastard instructed, bastard in mind, bastard in valour, in everything illegitimate. One bear will not bite another, and wherefore should one bastard? Take heed, the quarrel's most ominous to us: if the son of a whore fight for a whore, he tempts judgement. Farewell, bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Margarelon
dialogues.line: The devil take thee, coward!

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: Most putrified core so fair without, Thy goodly armour thus hath cost thy life. Now is my day's work done; I'll take my breath: Rest, sword; thou hast thy fill of blood and death!

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Look, Hector, how the sun begins to set, How ugly night comes breathing at his heels; Even with the vail and dark'ning of the sun, To close the day up, Hector's life is done.

dialogues.speaker: Hector
dialogues.line: I am unarm'd; forego this vantage, Greek.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: Strike, fellows, strike; this is the man I seek. So, Ilion, fall thou next! Now, Troy, sink down; Here lies thy heart, thy sinews, and thy bone. On, Myrmidons, and cry you all amain ‘Achilles hath the mighty Hector slain.' Hark! a retire upon our Grecian part.

dialogues.speaker: Myrmidon
dialogues.line: The Trojan trumpets sound the like, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Achilles
dialogues.line: The dragon wing of night o'erspreads the earth And, stickler-like, the armies separates. My half-supp'd sword, that frankly would have fed, Pleas'd with this dainty bait, thus goes to bed. Come, tie his body to my horse's tail; Along the field I will the Trojan trail.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: Hark! hark! what shout is this?

dialogues.speaker: Nestor
dialogues.line: Peace, drums!

dialogues.speaker: Soldiers
dialogues.line: Achilles! Achilles! Hector's slain. Achilles!

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: The bruit is, Hector's slain, and by Achilles.

dialogues.speaker: Ajax
dialogues.line: If it be so, yet bragless let it be; Great Hector was as good a man as he.

dialogues.speaker: Agamemnon
dialogues.line: March patiently along. Let one be sent To pray Achilles see us at our tent. If in his death the gods have us befriended; Great Troy is ours, and our sharp wars are ended.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: Stand, ho! yet are we masters of the field. Never go home; here starve we out the night.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hector is slain.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Hector! The gods forbid!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: He's dead, and at the murderer's horse's tail, In beastly sort, dragg'd through the shameful field. Frown on, you heavens, effect your rage with speed. Sit, gods, upon your thrones, and smile at Troy. I say at once let your brief plagues be mercy, And linger not our sure destructions on.

dialogues.speaker: Aeneas
dialogues.line: My lord, you do discomfort all the host.

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: You understand me not that tell me so. I do not speak of flight, of fear of death, But dare all imminence that gods and men Address their dangers in. Hector is gone. Who shall tell Priam so, or Hecuba? Let him that will a screech-owl aye be call'd Go in to Troy, and say there ‘Hector's dead.' There is a word will Priam turn to stone; Make wells and Niobes of the maids and wives, Cold statues of the youth; and, in a word, Scare Troy out of itself. But, march away; Hector is dead; there is no more to say. Stay yet. You vile abominable tents, Thus proudly pight upon our Phrygian plains, Let Titan rise as early as he dare, I'll through and through you. And, thou great-siz'd coward, No space of earth shall sunder our two hates; I'll haunt thee like a wicked conscience still, That mouldeth goblins swift as frenzy's thoughts. Strike a free march to Troy. With comfort go; Hope of revenge shall hide our inward woe.

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: But hear you, hear you!

dialogues.speaker: Troilus
dialogues.line: Hence, broker-lackey. Ignominy and shame Pursue thy life, and live aye with thy name!

dialogues.speaker: Pandarus
dialogues.line: A goodly medicine for my aching bones! O world! world! Thus is the poor agent despis'd! O traitors and bawds, how earnestly are you set a-work, and how ill requited! Why should our endeavour be so lov'd, and the performance so loathed? What verse for it? What instance for it? Let me see- Full merrily the humble-bee doth sing Till he hath lost his honey and his sting; And being once subdu'd in armed trail, Sweet honey and sweet notes together fail. Good traders in the flesh, set this in your painted cloths. As many as be here of Pandar's hall, Your eyes, half out, weep out at Pandar's fall; Or, if you cannot weep, yet give some groans, Though not for me, yet for your aching bones. Brethren and sisters of the hold-door trade, Some two months hence my will shall here be made. It should be now, but that my fear is this, Some galled goose of Winchester would hiss. Till then I'll sweat and seek about for eases, And at that time bequeath you my diseases.
